{"expire_at": null, "slug": "isengard", "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/homepage/location-index-page/isengard/", "body": "[{\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

In J. R. R. Tolkien's fictional universe of Middle-earth, Isengard ([\\u02c8a\\u026a\\u02d0.z\\u025bn.\\u0261\\u0251rd]), a translation of the Sindarin Angrenost, was a large fortress. Both names mean \\\"Iron fortress\\\" (cf. German Eisen and Old English is\\u00e6rn = iron),[1] though Isengard has a second meaning of \\\"West Guard\\\".

\"}, {\"type\": \"header\", \"value\": {\"header_text\": \"Armour and emblems\", \"size\": \"h2\"}}, {\"type\": \"image\", \"value\": {\"style\": \"half\", \"caption\": \"A shield displaying the White Hand of Isengard\", \"image\": 7}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

The Orcs of Isengard bore upon their shields a White Hand on a black field, and on their helmets an S-rune (<) to signify Saruman. A carved and painted White Hand of stone was set on a black pillar outside the gates of Isengard.

\"}, {\"type\": \"header\", \"value\": {\"header_text\": \"Orthanc\", \"size\": \"h2\"}}, {\"type\": \"blockquote\", \"value\": {\"attribute_group\": \"White wizard\", \"attribute_name\": \"Saruman\", \"text\": \"Against the power of Mordor there can be no victory\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Orthanc is the black tower of Isengard. Its name means both \\\"Mount Fang\\\" in Sindarin, and \\\"Cunning Mind\\\" in Old English, the language Tolkien uses to \\\"translate\\\" Rohirric.


Orthanc was, according to J. R. R. Tolkien's legendarium, built during the end of the Second Age by men of Gondor out of four many-sided columns of rock joined together by an unknown process and then hardened. No known weapon could harm it. Although the Ents could split ordinary stone with ease, their assault on the tower only left a few scratches and chips on its surface. Orthanc rose up to more than 500 feet (150 meters) above the plain of Isengard, and ended in four sharp peaks. Its only entrance was at the top of a high stair, and above that was a small window and balcony.


Orthanc housed one of the palant\\u00edri of the South Kingdom, and was guarded by a special warden. In the days of the early Stewards the tower was locked and its keys taken to Minas Tirith. When Isengard fell to the Dunlendings in T.A. 2710 they were unable to enter the tower.

\"}]", "first_published_at": null, "show_in_menus": false, "title": "Isengard", "pk": 14, "content_type": 6, "go_live_at": null, "expired": false, "seo_title": "", "search_description": "", "latest_revision_created_at": null, "depth": 4, "live": true, "image": 8, "owner": 1, "numchild": 0, "locked": false, "path": "0001000100030003"}

{"expire_at": null, "slug": "helms-deep", "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/homepage/location-index-page/helms-deep/", "body": "[{\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

In\\u00a0J. R. R. Tolkien's\\u00a0Middle-earth\\u00a0high fantasy\\u00a0writings,\\u00a0Helm's Deep\\u00a0was a large valley in the north-western\\u00a0Ered Nimrais\\u00a0(White Mountains).

The valley was described as being blocked over its entire width by the natural series of hills called\\u00a0Helm's Dike\\u00a0and behind that lay the fortress of Aglarond or the\\u00a0Hornburg, at the entrance to the Glittering Caves.

In the Appendices of\\u00a0The Lord of the Rings, the history of the valley states that it was home to a small\\u00a0Gondorian\\u00a0regiment, but after the place which was called\\u00a0Calenardhon\\u00a0became\\u00a0Rohan, it became an encampment of the\\u00a0Rohirrim, where the guards of the\\u00a0Fords of Isen\\u00a0lived.

It also states that during the war with the\\u00a0Dunlendings\\u00a0under\\u00a0Wulf, the Rohirrim under King\\u00a0Helm Hammerhand\\u00a0and many of his people sought refuge in the\\u00a0keep, where they held out during the winter of\\u00a0T.A.\\u00a02758\\u20132759.

The castle itself was described as having a long causeway which wound up to the great gate of the fortress itself. Inside the keep there were stables and an armoury, as well as a great hall in the rear which was dug out of the mountainside. There also was a great tower (the Hornburg) the top of which consisted of the great horn of\\u00a0Helm Hammerhand. The Deep, which was described as standing next to the fortress, was barred by the long Deeping Wall, which was described as consisting of solid rock except for a small culvert which allowed water from the Deeping Stream to enter; this rendered a fresh supply in sieges of great length. The Deeping Wall itself is described as standing 20 feet tall; and also being wide enough for four men to stand side by side. Access to the fortress from within the Deep was made possible by a long stair which led to the Hornburg's rear gate.

In\\u00a0The Two Towers, the fortress guarding Helm's Deep becomes the refuge of the main army of the Rohirrim, under King\\u00a0Th\\u00e9oden\\u00a0during the\\u00a0War of the Ring. Th\\u00e9oden said that \\\"the Hornburg has never fallen to assault\\\" giving an impression of invulnerability. This was tested during the\\u00a0Battle of the Hornburg, as a massive army of\\u00a0Uruk-hai\\u00a0sent by\\u00a0Saruman\\u00a0almost overwhelmed the defences of the Rohirrim. Saruman's\\u00a0orcs\\u00a0used an explosive blast of fire within the culvert which, when detonated, breached the long Deeping Wall. The origin of this explosion is unclear and Tolkien denotes it as \\\"Saruman's devilry\\\". The Rohirrim defenders held out long enough in the fortress until dawn, giving Gandalf time to gather and lead a counter-attack, while Th\\u00e9oden led a cavalry charge that drove the Orcs from the fortress.

\"}, {\"type\": \"image\", \"value\": {\"style\": \"full\", \"caption\": \"Crest of Gondor, keepers of the Helm\", \"image\": 9}}, {\"type\": \"header\", \"value\": {\"header_text\": \"Aglarond\", \"size\": \"h2\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Aglarond and Angrenost (which later became Isengard) were the two fortresses built by Gondor to guard the approaches to the Fords of Isen. Like Angrenost to the north, it was initially well guarded, but as the population of Calenardhon (the later Rohan) dwindled it was not maintained and, losing importance, was left to a hereditary small guard who intermarried with Dunlendings.


When Cirion, Steward of Gondor, gave Calenardhon to the \\u00c9oth\\u00e9od, Aglarond was transferred into the care of the Rohirrim, who named it S\\u00fathburg (southern burg in their language). The Gondorian guard was merged with that of Angrenost to the north, which remained in the keep of Gondor. Guard duty of the Fords was initially shared between Gondor and Rohan, but later maintained only by the Rohirrim.


During the reign of Helm Hammerhand, Rohan was attacked by Dunlendings from across the river Isen. Edoras was taken, and Helm and many of his people retreated to S\\u00fathburg. Because Helm always blew a great horn before riding out to fight the beleaguering Dunlendings, the keep was renamed Hornburg. During the War of the Ring, the Hornburg was the refuge of the Rohirrim as they defended Helm's Deep.


After the war, Gimli the Dwarf, who fought in that battle, established a colony of Durin's folk there. Aglarond lay in front of a huge and very beautiful cave system, which proved irresistible to him. Gimli became known as 'the Lord of the Glittering Caves', although this new realm was presumably under the overlordship of Thorin Stonehelm, his kinsman and heir of the lordship of all Durin's Folk. The dwarves of Aglarond restored the Hornburg following the War of the Ring, and it became a fortress they shared with the Rohirrim.

\"}]", "first_published_at": null, "show_in_menus": false, "title": "Helm's Deep", "pk": 15, "content_type": 6, "go_live_at": null, "expired": false, "seo_title": "", "search_description": "", "latest_revision_created_at": null, "depth": 4, "live": true, "image": 10, "owner": 1, "numchild": 0, "locked": false, "path": "0001000100030004"}

{"expire_at": null, "slug": "helms-deep", "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/homepage/location-index-page/helms-deep/", "body": "[{\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

In\\u00a0J. R. R. Tolkien's\\u00a0Middle-earth\\u00a0high fantasy\\u00a0writings,\\u00a0Helm's Deep\\u00a0was a large valley in the north-western\\u00a0Ered Nimrais\\u00a0(White Mountains).

The valley was described as being blocked over its entire width by the natural series of hills called\\u00a0Helm's Dike\\u00a0and behind that lay the fortress of Aglarond or the\\u00a0Hornburg, at the entrance to the Glittering Caves.

In the Appendices of\\u00a0The Lord of the Rings, the history of the valley states that it was home to a small\\u00a0Gondorian\\u00a0regiment, but after the place which was called\\u00a0Calenardhon\\u00a0became\\u00a0Rohan, it became an encampment of the\\u00a0Rohirrim, where the guards of the\\u00a0Fords of Isen\\u00a0lived.

It also states that during the war with the\\u00a0Dunlendings\\u00a0under\\u00a0Wulf, the Rohirrim under King\\u00a0Helm Hammerhand\\u00a0and many of his people sought refuge in the\\u00a0keep, where they held out during the winter of\\u00a0T.A.\\u00a02758\\u20132759.

The castle itself was described as having a long causeway which wound up to the great gate of the fortress itself. Inside the keep there were stables and an armoury, as well as a great hall in the rear which was dug out of the mountainside. There also was a great tower (the Hornburg) the top of which consisted of the great horn of\\u00a0Helm Hammerhand. The Deep, which was described as standing next to the fortress, was barred by the long Deeping Wall, which was described as consisting of solid rock except for a small culvert which allowed water from the Deeping Stream to enter; this rendered a fresh supply in sieges of great length. The Deeping Wall itself is described as standing 20 feet tall; and also being wide enough for four men to stand side by side. Access to the fortress from within the Deep was made possible by a long stair which led to the Hornburg's rear gate.

In\\u00a0The Two Towers, the fortress guarding Helm's Deep becomes the refuge of the main army of the Rohirrim, under King\\u00a0Th\\u00e9oden\\u00a0during the\\u00a0War of the Ring. Th\\u00e9oden said that \\\"the Hornburg has never fallen to assault\\\" giving an impression of invulnerability. This was tested during the\\u00a0Battle of the Hornburg, as a massive army of\\u00a0Uruk-hai\\u00a0sent by\\u00a0Saruman\\u00a0almost overwhelmed the defences of the Rohirrim. Saruman's\\u00a0orcs\\u00a0used an explosive blast of fire within the culvert which, when detonated, breached the long Deeping Wall. The origin of this explosion is unclear and Tolkien denotes it as \\\"Saruman's devilry\\\". The Rohirrim defenders held out long enough in the fortress until dawn, giving Gandalf time to gather and lead a counter-attack, while Th\\u00e9oden led a cavalry charge that drove the Orcs from the fortress.

\"}, {\"type\": \"image\", \"value\": {\"style\": \"full\", \"caption\": \"Crest of Gondor, the original builders of the Helm\", \"image\": 9}}, {\"type\": \"header\", \"value\": {\"header_text\": \"Aglarond\", \"size\": \"h2\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Aglarond and Angrenost (which later became Isengard) were the two fortresses built by Gondor to guard the approaches to the Fords of Isen. Like Angrenost to the north, it was initially well guarded, but as the population of Calenardhon (the later Rohan) dwindled it was not maintained and, losing importance, was left to a hereditary small guard who intermarried with Dunlendings.


When Cirion, Steward of Gondor, gave Calenardhon to the \\u00c9oth\\u00e9od, Aglarond was transferred into the care of the Rohirrim, who named it S\\u00fathburg (southern burg in their language). The Gondorian guard was merged with that of Angrenost to the north, which remained in the keep of Gondor. Guard duty of the Fords was initially shared between Gondor and Rohan, but later maintained only by the Rohirrim.


During the reign of Helm Hammerhand, Rohan was attacked by Dunlendings from across the river Isen. Edoras was taken, and Helm and many of his people retreated to S\\u00fathburg. Because Helm always blew a great horn before riding out to fight the beleaguering Dunlendings, the keep was renamed Hornburg. During the War of the Ring, the Hornburg was the refuge of the Rohirrim as they defended Helm's Deep.


After the war, Gimli the Dwarf, who fought in that battle, established a colony of Durin's folk there. Aglarond lay in front of a huge and very beautiful cave system, which proved irresistible to him. Gimli became known as 'the Lord of the Glittering Caves', although this new realm was presumably under the overlordship of Thorin Stonehelm, his kinsman and heir of the lordship of all Durin's Folk. The dwarves of Aglarond restored the Hornburg following the War of the Ring, and it became a fortress they shared with the Rohirrim.

\"}]", "first_published_at": "2017-01-12T19:51:43.011Z", "show_in_menus": false, "title": "Helm's Deep", "pk": 15, "content_type": 6, "go_live_at": null, "expired": false, "seo_title": "", "search_description": "", "latest_revision_created_at": "2017-01-12T19:51:42.977Z", "depth": 4, "live": true, "image": 10, "owner": 1, "numchild": 0, "locked": false, "path": "0001000100030004"}

{"expire_at": null, "slug": "edoras", "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/homepage/location-index-page/edoras/", "body": "[{\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

The capital of Rohan is the hill fort of Edoras which is located on a hill in a valley of the White Mountains. Meduseld, the Golden Hall of the King of Rohan, is located there. \\\"Edoras\\\" is Old English for \\\"enclosures\\\",[4] which Tolkien held to be a translation of an unknown Rohirric name of the same meaning. The city of Edoras was built by Rohan's second King, Brego son of Eorl the Young. Before Edoras was completed, Rohan's capital was at Aldburg in the Folde. Meduseld is described as having a golden thatch. Edoras is built at the end of the valley of Harrowdale, which lies under the great mountain Starkhorn. The river Snowbourn flows past the city on its way east towards the Entwash. The city is protected only by a high wall of timber, and a one-way road allows access to the city. Just before the gates, two rows of mounds line the road, which are the graves of the former Kings of Rohan. \\\"Meduseld\\\", a modernised form of the Old English Maeduselde,[5] is similarly meant to be a translation of an unknown Rohirric name meaning \\\"mead hall\\\". Meduseld is a large hall with roof that appears golden from far off. The walls are richly decorated with tapestries depicting the history and legends of the Rohirrim, and it serves as a house for the King and his kin, a meeting hall for the King and his advisors, and a gathering hall.

\"}, {\"type\": \"image\", \"value\": {\"style\": \"half\", \"caption\": \"The Uffington White Horse, whence the banner and shield of the House of Eorl \\u2013 a \\\"white horse upon green\\\" \\u2013 is derived.\", \"image\": 11}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Edoras is Rohan's only real city. It is at Meduseld that Aragorn, Gimli, Legolas, and Gandalf meet with King Th\\u00e9oden in the account of the early stages of the War of the Ring.

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Another settlement is Aldburg, capital of the Eastfold and original settlement of Eorl the Young. A third settlement is Snowbourne, named after the river of the same name which runs nearby. It is similar in appearance to the hill-fort of Edoras. Dunharrow is a refuge in the White Mountains. Helm's Deep is a valley in the White Mountains in which the Hornburg, a major fortress of Rohan, is located.

\"}, {\"type\": \"blockquote\", \"value\": {\"attribute_group\": \"Reciting a forgotten poem on Eorl the Young\", \"attribute_name\": \"Aragorn\", \"text\": \"Where now the horse and the rider? Where is the horn that was blowing?\\r\\nWhere is the helm and the hauberk, and the bright hair flowing?\\r\\nWhere is the hand on the harp-string, and the red fire glowing?\\r\\nWhere is the spring and the harvest and the tall corn growing?\"}}, {\"type\": \"header\", \"value\": {\"header_text\": \"Internal history\", \"size\": \"h2\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

In the thirteenth century of the Third Age (T.A.), the Kings of Gondor made close alliances with the Northmen of Rhovanion, a people said in The Lord of the Rings to be akin to the Three Houses of Men (later the D\\u00fanedain) from the First Age.


In the twenty-first century, a remnant tribe of such Northmen calling itself the \\u00c9oth\\u00e9od moved from the valleys of Anduin to the north west of Mirkwood, clearing out what remained of the recently defeated witch kingdom of Angmar, east of the Misty Mountains. While there, some dispute arose between them and the Dwarves over the treasure-hoard of Scatha the dragon.


Later, in 2509, Cirion the Steward of Gondor sent summons to the \\u00c9oth\\u00e9od for aid in throwing off a combined invasion of Men from the north east of Middle-earth, and Orcs from Mordor.


Eorl the Young, king of the \\u00c9oth\\u00e9od, answered the summons, and arrived unexpected at a decisive battle at the Field of Celebrant, routing the orc army, and then destroying it as it fled.


As a reward, Eorl was given the plains of Calenardhon, and he moved his kingdom there. This land had earlier been part of Gondor proper, but had been devastated by the plague of 1636, and the survivors to a large extent slain in the invasion mentioned above.


The first line of kings lasted for 249 years, until the ninth king Helm Hammerhand died. His sons had been killed earlier, and his nephew Fr\\u00e9al\\u00e1f Hildeson began the second line of kings, which lasted until the end of the Third Age.


In 2758, Rohan was invaded by Dunlendings under Wulf, son of Freca, of mixed Dunland and Rohan blood. The King, Helm Hammerhand, took refuge in the Hornburg until aid from Gondor and Dunharrow (a refuge of the Rohirrim) arrived a year later and defeated the invaders.

\"}, {\"type\": \"embed\", \"value\": \"https://www.youtube.com/embed/SLxeNktacYs\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

It was soon after this that Saruman arrived and took over Isengard, and was welcomed as a strong ally, since it would take Rohan close to 200 years to recover its strength after the invasion.


In 3014, Saruman began using his influence to weaken the King, Th\\u00e9oden, as part of a campaign to invade or take over the kingdom. In 3019, he launched a great invasion of Rohan, with victory in the two first battles (at the Fords of Isen; Th\\u00e9oden's son, Th\\u00e9odred was killed during these attacks) and defeat at the Battle of the Hornburg, where the Huorns came to the aid of the Rohirrim.


On the heels of this victory, Th\\u00e9oden rode with an army to Minas Tirith and helped break its siege in the Battle of the Pelennor Fields, where he was slain. \\u00c9omer, the nephew of King Th\\u00e9oden, then took up the reign, beginning the third line. Also in this battle, \\u00c9owyn, niece of King Th\\u00e9oden and sister of \\u00c9omer, slew the Lord of the Nazg\\u00fbl. \\u00c9omer rode with the armies of Gondor to the Black Gate of Mordor and took part in the Battle of the Morannon against the forces of Sauron, who were defeated when the Ruling Ring was destroyed.


The rule of the Stewards of Gondor was then over. King \\u00c9omer and the new king of Gondor, Elessar, renewed their oath of alliance, and reaffirmed Cirion's grant of Calenardhon to the Rohirrim. At this time, \\u00c9owyn married Faramir, Prince of Ithilien and Steward of Gondor, thus joining the lines of Gondor and Rohan.


In the Fourth Age, Rohan remained in peaceful coexistence with the Reunited Kingdom. A Dwarven community developed in the caves of Helm's Deep, which became prosperous from its mining of precious materials.

\"}]", "first_published_at": null, "show_in_menus": false, "title": "Edoras", "pk": 16, "content_type": 6, "go_live_at": null, "expired": false, "seo_title": "", "search_description": "", "latest_revision_created_at": null, "depth": 4, "live": true, "image": 12, "owner": 1, "numchild": 0, "locked": false, "path": "0001000100030005"}

{"expire_at": null, "slug": "fangorn", "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/homepage/location-index-page/fangorn/", "body": "[{\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Fangorn (Sindarin: [Fangaorne]; \\\"Beardtree\\\") in J.R.R. Tolkien's Legendarium, was a forest located in the fictional world of Middle-earth and was the home of the tree shepherds, the Ents. It was named after the oldest Ent, Treebeard or Treebeard after it. Tolkien did, however, state that there was confusion about the two.


The Forest of Fangorn provided an important role in The Lord of the Rings novel as did Mirkwood and Lothl\\u00f3rien in the Third Age, a time when Sauron challenged Middle-earth to battle and domination. The forest provided the means by where adventure expanded with the breaking up of the Fellowship. Merry Brandybuck and Peregrin Took were the first to discover the Ents were alive but were dwindling in numbers due to the loss of the Entwives. They were lost because of the events of the Last Alliance of Elves and Men. The forest was again severely damaged during the War of the Ring by the forces of Saruman who lived close by in the fortress of Isengard.

\"}, {\"type\": \"header\", \"value\": {\"header_text\": \"Etymology\", \"size\": \"h2\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

\\\"Fangorn\\\" was the original name for the Ent Treebeard, who was the eldest of his species and who looked after vast areas of his home and the surrounding land which was named Fangorn Forest. Additionally, Fangorn translated in the fictional language of Sindarin from \\\"fanga\\\" meaning \\\"beard\\\" and \\\"orne\\\" meaning \\\"tree\\\". Sindarin was a language Tolkien created and described the Elves of Middle-Earth to possess; who \\\"awoke\\\" the Ents and taught them language. In other parts of Middle-earth Fangorn Forest was called the \\\"Entwood\\\" by the Rohirrim.

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Fangorn Forest apparently had several names as told by Treebeard who referred to the forest by various Quenya names in Lord of the Rings, some of which were Ambar\\u00f3na, Tauremornal\\u00f3m\\u00eb, Tauremorna and Aldal\\u00f3m\\u00eb. \\\"Ambar\\u00f3na\\\" means \\\"uprising, sunrise, orient\\\" from \\\"amba\\\" meaning \\\"upwards\\\" and \\\"r\\u00f3na\\\" meaning \\\"east\\\". \\\"Aldal\\u00f3m\\u00eb\\\" means \\\"tree twilight\\\" from \\\"alda\\\" meaning \\\"tree\\\" and \\\"l\\u00f3m\\u00eb\\\" meaning \\\"dusk, twilight\\\".[1] \\\"Tauremorna\\\" means \\\"gloomy forest\\\" from \\\"taur\\\" meaning \\\"forest\\\" and \\\"morna\\\" meaning \\\"gloomy, somber\\\".[1] \\\"Tauremornal\\u00f3m\\u00eb\\\" means \\\"gloomy twilight forest\\\".

\"}, {\"type\": \"header\", \"value\": {\"header_text\": \"Geography\", \"size\": \"h2\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

The Forest of Fangorn was located at the south-eastern end of the Misty Mountains near the Gap of Rohan. The mountains formed the western border of Fangorn. At the end of the mountain range stood the stronghold of Isengard near the southwestern corner of the forest and this was where Saruman lived.[citation needed] To the east and south of Fangorn was the land of Rohan, and Lothl\\u00f3rien lay to the north and slightly east. Fangorn Forest stretched for many miles and held many paths.


Tolkien stated that two significant rivers ran through the forest. To the north the Limlight flowed from the woods and then formed the northern border of Rohan. The river then merged into the larger Anduin. In the south, the Entwash spread deep into the forest arriving from Methedras, a mountainous region located near the Misty Mountains. The river then flowed from Fangorn and was directed through Rohan to the Anduin River. The valley of Derndingle was located to the south-west. There was a path where the Entwash passed into a region called Wellinghall and this was where the Entwash passed the home of Treebeard, the shepherd of the forest.


\"}, {\"type\": \"blockquote\", \"value\": {\"attribute_group\": \"\", \"attribute_name\": \"Treebeard\", \"text\": \"Some of us are still true Ents, and lively enough in our fashion, but many are growing sleepy, going tree-ish, as you might say. Most of the trees are just trees, of course; but many are half awake. Some are quite wide awake, and a few are, well, ah, well getting Entish. That is going on all the time.\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Fangorn Forest was said to be humid, and trunks and branches grew thick where very little light penetrated the forest. Similarly, Fangorn was said to be a dangerous and evil place like Mirkwood (where huge spiders roamed the forest and other evil creatures lay), but this was not the case following the events of The Lord of the Rings. The forest was home to many different kinds of trees. Huorns also lived in the forest, similar to Ents but more discreet. Most lived deep in the Forest of Fangorn. The Ents and Huorns drank from the river Entwash, and from it the Ents brewed their legendary drink, the Ent-draughts.

\"}]", "first_published_at": null, "show_in_menus": false, "title": "Fangorn", "pk": 17, "content_type": 6, "go_live_at": null, "expired": false, "seo_title": "", "search_description": "", "latest_revision_created_at": null, "depth": 4, "live": true, "image": 13, "owner": 1, "numchild": 0, "locked": false, "path": "0001000100030006"}

{"expire_at": null, "slug": "shire", "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/homepage/location-index-page/shire/", "body": "[{\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

The Shire is a region of J. R. R. Tolkien's fictional Middle-earth, described in The Lord of the Rings and other works. The Shire refers to an area settled exclusively by Hobbits and largely removed from the goings-on in the rest of Middle-earth. It is located in the northwest of the continent, in the large region of Eriador and the Kingdom of Arnor. In the languages invented by Tolkien, its name in Westron was S\\u00fbza \\\"Shire\\\"[1] or S\\u00fbzat \\\"The Shire\\\",[2] while its name in Sindarin was i Drann.[3]

\"}, {\"type\": \"header\", \"value\": {\"header_text\": \"Geography\", \"size\": \"h2\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

According to Tolkien, the Shire measured 40 leagues (193 km, 120 miles[4]) from the Far Downs in the west to the Brandywine Bridge in the east, and 50 leagues (241 km, 150 miles) from the northern moors to the marshes in the south.[5] This is confirmed in an essay by Tolkien on translating The Lord of the Rings,[6] where he describes the Shire as having an area of 18,000 square miles (47,000 km2).[7]

\"}, {\"type\": \"embed\", \"value\": \"https://youtu.be/Ti5OaadrS9I\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

The original territory of the Shire was bounded on the east by the Baranduin River, on the north by uplands rising to the old centre of Arnor, on the west by the White Downs, and on the south by marshland south of the River Shirebourn. After the original settlement, hobbits also expanded to the east into Buckland between the Baranduin and the Old Forest, and (much later) to the west into the Westmarch between the White Downs and the Tower Hills.[8]

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

The Shire was originally divided into four Farthings. The outlying lands of Buckland and the Westmarch were formally added after the War of the Ring.[5] Within the Farthings there are some smaller unofficial clan homelands: the Tooks nearly all live in or near Tuckborough in Tookland, for instance. A Hobbit surname often indicates where the family came from: Samwise Gamgee's last name derives from Gamwich, where the family originated. Buckland was named for the Oldbucks (later called the Brandybucks).

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

The Shire is described as a small but beautiful, idyllic and fruitful land, beloved by its inhabitants. The Hobbits had an extensive agricultural system in the Shire but were not industrialised. The landscape included small pockets of forest (again similar to the English countryside). Various supplies were produced in the Shire, including cereals, fruit, wood and pipe-weed.

\"}, {\"type\": \"header\", \"value\": {\"header_text\": \"Regions of the Shire\", \"size\": \"h2\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

The original parts of the Shire were subdivided into four Farthings (\\\"fourth-ings\\\" or \\\"quarterings\\\").[9] The Three-Farthing Stone marked the tripoint where the borders of the Eastfarthing, Westfarthing and Southfarthing of the Shire came together, by the East Road.[10] (Iceland was traditionally also divided in Farthings, or \\\"fourth parts\\\", as the Shire is.) It is claimed that the Three-Farthing Stone was inspired by the Four shire stone.[11]


Buckland, across the Baranduin River to the east, and the Westmarch, between the Far Downs and the Tower Hills to the west, were not part of the original grant to the hobbits by King Argeleb II of Arthedain. These were formally given to the hobbits as the East and West Marches of the Shire by King Elessar after the War of the Ring, in S.R. 1462 (F.A. 41).[9][12] Buckland had been long settled by then: Gorhendad Oldbuck led hobbits from the East Farthing across the river in T.A. 2340,[12] and Buckland became \\\"sort of a colony of the Shire\\\".[13] There is no mention of settlement in the Westmarch until Elessar's gift; Sam Gamgee's daughter Elanor and her husband Fastred later settled there, and Fastred was created Warden of Westmarch.

\"}]", "first_published_at": null, "show_in_menus": false, "title": "The Shire", "pk": 18, "content_type": 6, "go_live_at": null, "expired": false, "seo_title": "", "search_description": "", "latest_revision_created_at": null, "depth": 4, "live": true, "image": 14, "owner": 1, "numchild": 0, "locked": false, "path": "0001000100030007"}

{"expire_at": null, "slug": "rivendell", "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/homepage/location-index-page/rivendell/", "body": "[{\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Rivendell is an Elven realm in Middle-earth, a fictional world created by J. R. R. Tolkien. It is an important location in Tolkien's legendarium, and is featured in The Hobbit, The Lord of the Rings, The Silmarillion, and Unfinished Tales. It was established and ruled by Elrond Half-elven in the Second Age of Middle-earth (four or five thousand years before the events of The Lord of the Rings), and was protected by the powers of its lord and his elven ring Vilya.


Elrond lived in Rivendell with his family \\u2014 his wife Celebr\\u00edan (until she departed for Valinor), their sons Elladan and Elrohir, and their daughter Arwen \\u2014 as well as a sizeable number of other Elves, both Noldor and Sindar. In addition to the family of Elrond, notable Elves who lived in Rivendell included Glorfindel, Gildor, and Erestor. In some writings, featured in Unfinished Tales, Galadriel and Celeborn also lived in Rivendell for a time before they became rulers of Lothl\\u00f3rien.

\"}, {\"type\": \"embed\", \"value\": \"https://youtu.be/t9L8Er_oqAQ\"}, {\"type\": \"header\", \"value\": {\"header_text\": \"Etymology\", \"size\": \"h2\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Rivendell\\u00a0is a direct translation or\\u00a0calque\\u00a0into English of the\\u00a0Sindarin\\u00a0name\\u00a0Imladris, both meaning \\\"deep valley of the cleft\\\". The name Rivendell is formed by two English elements: \\\"riven\\\" (split, cloven) and \\\"dell\\\" (valley), making the whole word purport \\\"deeply cloven valley\\\". Imladris was also rendered \\\"Karningul\\\" in\\u00a0Westron, the \\\"Common Tongue\\\" of Middle-Earth represented as English in the text of\\u00a0The Lord of the Rings.\\u00a0It is also referred to as\\u00a0The Last Homely House,\\u00a0alluding to the elves' old cities, in Beleriand and Aman, and the wilderness (Rhovanion) that lies east of the Misty Mountains.

\"}, {\"type\": \"header\", \"value\": {\"header_text\": \"Legacy\", \"size\": \"h2\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

In the period of\\u00a0counterculture\\u00a0in the\\u00a0Western World\\u00a0of the 1960s and 1970s, a\\u00a0commune\\u00a0called\\u00a0Maos Lyst\\u00a0(Mao's Delight) was founded in\\u00a0Denmark\\u00a0in 1968, its inhabitants replacing their surnames with\\u00a0Kl\\u00f8vedal, Danish for Rivendell, inspired by Tolkien's Elven outpost.[6]\\u00a0Several of them later became well-known cultural personalities in the country.

The Canadian progressive rock band\\u00a0Rush\\u00a0memorializes Rivendell in the song \\\"Rivendell\\\" on their second studio album\\u00a0Fly By Night. The song focuses on the tranquillity and seemingly endless time a weary traveller could find there.

The Austrian folk band Rivendell takes the material for their lyrics almost entirely from Tolkien's books.

A Californian manufacturer of bicycles,\\u00a0Rivendell Bicycle Works, also uses the name, inspired by the book and a United States backpacking supply company founded in the 1970s called\\u00a0Rivendell Mountain Works. They take many of the names of their bicycle models from Tolkien.[7]

\"}]", "first_published_at": null, "show_in_menus": false, "title": "Rivendell", "pk": 19, "content_type": 6, "go_live_at": null, "expired": false, "seo_title": "", "search_description": "", "latest_revision_created_at": null, "depth": 4, "live": true, "image": 15, "owner": 1, "numchild": 0, "locked": false, "path": "0001000100030008"}

{"expire_at": null, "slug": "mordor", "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/homepage/location-index-page/mordor/", "body": "[{\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

In\\u00a0J. R. R. Tolkien's\\u00a0fictional world\\u00a0of\\u00a0Middle-earth,\\u00a0Mordor\\u00a0(pronounced\\u00a0[\\u02c8m\\u0254rd\\u0254r]; from\\u00a0Sindarin\\u00a0Black Land\\u00a0and\\u00a0Quenya\\u00a0Land of Shadow) was the region occupied and controlled by\\u00a0Sauron, in the southeast of northwestern Middle-earth to the East of\\u00a0Anduin, the great river.\\u00a0Orodruin, a volcano in Mordor, was the goal of the\\u00a0Fellowship of the Ring\\u00a0(and later\\u00a0Frodo Baggins\\u00a0and\\u00a0Sam Gamgee) in the quest to destroy the\\u00a0One Ring.

Mordor has three enormous mountain ranges surrounding it, from the north, from the west and from the south. The mountains both protected the land from an unexpected invasion by any of the people living in those directions and kept those living in Mordor from escaping. Tolkien was reported to have identified Mordor with the volcano of\\u00a0Stromboli\\u00a0off Sicily, in terms of geographic equivalency with the real world.

\"}, {\"type\": \"image\", \"value\": {\"style\": \"full\", \"caption\": \"Barad-d\\u00fbr looking over Mount Doom\", \"image\": 16}}, {\"type\": \"header\", \"value\": {\"header_text\": \"Geography\", \"size\": \"h2\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Three sides of Mordor were bounded by mountain ranges, arranged in a rough rectangle: the Ered Lithui (translated as 'Ash Mountains') on the north, and the Ephel D\\u00faath (literally, \\\"Fence of Shadow\\\") on the west and the south. In the northwest the pass of Cirith Gorgor led into the enclosed plain of Ud\\u00fbn. Sauron built the Black Gate of Mordor (the Morannon) across the pass, joining the Towers of the Teeth, two earlier guard towers built by Gondor to keep a watch on this entrance. The passage through the inner side of Ud\\u00fbn into the interior of Mordor was guarded by another gate, the Isenmouthe. Outside the Morannon lay the Dagorlad or Battle Plain.

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

In the interior within this mountainous border lay Sauron's main fortress Barad-d\\u00fbr, the arid plateau of Gorgoroth, and Mount Doom. To the east lay the plain of Lithlad. A narrow pass led through the Ephel D\\u00faath, guarded by Minas Morgul (earlier Minas Ithil). A higher, more difficult pass, Cirith Ungol, just to the north, was guarded by a tower originally built by Gondor. This pass, \\\"the pass of the spider\\\", was also blockaded by Torech Ungol, the lair of the giant spider Shelob. The fortress Durthang lay in the northern Ephel D\\u00faath above Ud\\u00fbn.

\"}, {\"type\": \"embed\", \"value\": \"https://youtu.be/jk9wwlzuwJE\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

N\\u00farn, the southern part of Mordor, was less arid and more fertile. Streams here fed the salt Sea of N\\u00farnen. Sauron's slaves farmed this region to support his armies.

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Inside the Ephel D\\u00faath ran a lower parallel ridge, the Morgai, separated from the Ephel D\\u00faath by a narrow valley that Frodo and Sam followed northward after escaping from Cirith Ungol. Water trickled into this vale from the Ephel D\\u00faath, and the text describes it as a \\\"dying land not yet dead\\\". The vegetation included \\\"low scrubby trees\\\", \\\"coarse grey grass-tussocks\\\", \\\"withered mosses\\\", \\\"great writhing, tangled brambles\\\", and thickets of briars with long, stabbing thorns. The fauna included maggots, midges, and flies marked with \\\"a red eye-shaped blotch\\\".

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Adjacent to Mordor were, to the west, the narrow land of Ithilien (a province of Gondor); to the northwest the Dead Marshes; to the northeast Rh\\u00fbn; to the southeast Khand; and to the south Harad.

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

In The Atlas of Middle-earth, Karen Wynn Fonstad assumed that the lands of Mordor, Khand, and Rh\\u00fbn lay where the inland Sea of Helcar had been, and that the Sea of Rh\\u00fbn and Sea of N\\u00farnen were its remnants. This assumption stemmed from a First Age world-map drawn by Tolkien in the Ambarkanta, where the Inland Sea of Helcar occupied a large area of Middle-earth between the Ered Luin and Orocarni, with the western end being close to the head of the Great Gulf (later the Mouths of Anduin).[2] The atlas was however published before The Peoples of Middle-earth, in which the Sea of Rh\\u00fbn and Mordor exist already in the First Age.

\"}]", "first_published_at": "2016-10-24T15:19:13.969Z", "show_in_menus": false, "title": "Mordor", "pk": 8, "content_type": 6, "go_live_at": null, "expired": false, "seo_title": "", "search_description": "", "latest_revision_created_at": "2017-01-09T10:57:20.972Z", "depth": 4, "live": true, "image": 5, "owner": 1, "numchild": 0, "locked": false, "path": "0001000100030001"}

{"expire_at": null, "slug": "minas-tirith", "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/homepage/location-index-page/minas-tirith/", "body": "[{\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Minas Tirith\\u00a0(/\\u02c8m\\u026an\\u0259s\\u00a0\\u02c8t\\u026ar\\u026a\\u03b8/;\\u00a0Sindarin:\\u00a0/\\u02c8minas \\u02c8tiri\\u03b8/), originally named\\u00a0Minas Anor, is a fictional city and castle in\\u00a0J. R. R. Tolkien's\\u00a0Middle-earth\\u00a0writings. It became the heavily fortified\\u00a0capital\\u00a0of\\u00a0Gondor\\u00a0in the second half of the\\u00a0Third Age. It was originally built to guard the former capital,\\u00a0Osgiliath, from attack from the west, but became the capital when Osgiliath fell into ruin following the\\u00a0Kin-strife\\u00a0and the\\u00a0Great Plague. It is often referred to as the\\u00a0White City\\u00a0(though that name is not in the book) and the\\u00a0City of the Kings. The\\u00a0Rohirrimsometimes translated this into\\u00a0their own language\\u00a0as \\\"the\\u00a0Mundburg\\\". In the climax of\\u00a0The Lord of the Rings\\u00a0the city comes under a very large and determined attack by the allied forces of\\u00a0Mordor.

\"}, {\"type\": \"header\", \"value\": {\"header_text\": \"Description\", \"size\": \"h2\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

The name\\u00a0Minas Tirith\\u00a0means \\\"The Tower of Guard\\\" or \\\"The Tower of Watch\\\" in the\\u00a0Elvish\\u00a0language\\u00a0Sindarin.[1]\\u00a0It was originally named\\u00a0Minas Anor, \\\"The Tower of the Setting Sun\\\", in connection with\\u00a0Minas Ithil, \\\"The Tower of the Rising Moon\\\". Minas Ithil was later conquered by\\u00a0orcs\\u00a0from\\u00a0Mordor\\u00a0and was renamed\\u00a0Minas Morgul, \\\"The Tower of Black Sorcery\\\".

The city of Minas Tirith covered an entire hill, the Hill of Guard, and was built on seven levels, culminating in the Citadel at the summit. Each level was about 100\\u00a0ft (30\\u00a0m) higher than the one below it, and each surrounded by a white wall, with the exception of the wall of the First Circle (the lowest level), which was black. The outer face of this outer wall, the lowest, was made of black stone, the same material used in\\u00a0Orthanc; it was vulnerable only to earthquakes capable of rending the ground where it stood.[2]

Each wall held a gate, and each gate faced a different direction from the one in the next lower wall. The city's main street snaked up the hill and through each of the gates.

\"}, {\"type\": \"image\", \"value\": {\"style\": \"full\", \"caption\": \"White Tree of Gondor in Minas Tirith\", \"image\": 17}}, {\"type\": \"header\", \"value\": {\"header_text\": \"Great Gate\", \"size\": \"h2\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

The Great Gate was the main gate on the first level of the City of Minas Tirith. It was in the City Wall \\u2014 or Othram \\u2014 facing eastward across the Pelennor Fields toward the\\u00a0Anduin.

In front of the Great Gate there was a large paved area called the Gateway. The main roads to Minas Tirith met here: the\\u00a0North-way\\u00a0that became the\\u00a0Great West Road\\u00a0to\\u00a0Rohan; the\\u00a0South Road\\u00a0to the southern provinces of Gondor; and the\\u00a0road to Osgiliath.

The Great Gate was very strong, constructed of iron and steel and guarded by stone towers and bastions. The iron doors of the Gate rolled back to open. Passwords were required to enter the Great Gate and each of the six other gates of Minas Tirith. The Great Gate was breached during the\\u00a0War of the Ring.\\u00a0Sauron's forces under the command of the\\u00a0Witch-king of Angmar\\u00a0besieged the City on 13th 'March'. Before dawn on 15th 'March', the battering ram\\u00a0Grond\\u00a0smashed into the Great Gate three times while the Witch-king spoke words of power. \\\"As if stricken by some blasting spell it burst asunder: there was a flash of searing lightning, and the doors tumbled in riven fragments to the ground.\\\"[3]\\u00a0The Witch-king rode through the Gate where\\u00a0Gandalf\\u00a0awaited him, but then the Rohirrim arrived and the Witch-king went to fight them in the\\u00a0Battle of the Pelennor Fields\\u00a0where he was slain.

A temporary barricade was erected in place of the Great Gate. After the War, on 1st 'May',\\u00a0Aragorn\\u00a0received the\\u00a0Crown of Gondor\\u00a0in front of the gate and then entered the City.

The Great Gate was rebuilt of\\u00a0mithril\\u00a0(the hardest of all metals in Tolkien's writing) and steel by\\u00a0Gimli\\u00a0and Dwarves of\\u00a0Erebor\\u00a0from the\\u00a0Lonely Mountain\\u00a0who had settled in the\\u00a0Glittering Caves.

\"}]", "first_published_at": "2017-01-09T10:57:05.960Z", "show_in_menus": false, "title": "Minas Tirith", "pk": 12, "content_type": 6, "go_live_at": null, "expired": false, "seo_title": "", "search_description": "", "latest_revision_created_at": "2017-01-09T10:57:05.919Z", "depth": 4, "live": true, "image": 4, "owner": 1, "numchild": 0, "locked": false, "path": "0001000100030002"}

{"expire_at": null, "slug": "person", "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/homepage/index-page/person/", "body": "[{\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Aragorn is the son of Arathorn. He is one of the main protagonists of The Lord of the Rings. Aragorn was a Ranger of the North, first introduced with the name Strider at Bree, as the Hobbits continued to call him throughout The Lord of the Rings. He was eventually discovered to be the heir of Isildur and rightful claimant to the thrones of Arnor and Gondor. He was also a confidant of Gandalf and an integral part of the quest to destroy the One Ring and defeat the Dark Lord Sauron.

\"}, {\"type\": \"blockquote\", \"value\": {\"attribute_group\": \"\", \"attribute_name\": \"Aragorn\", \"text\": \"Let's hunt some Orc.\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Aragorn led the Fellowship of the Ring following the loss of Gandalf in the Mines of Moria while fighting the Balrog. When the Fellowship was broken, he tracked the hobbits Meriadoc Brandybuck and Peregrin Took with the help of Legolas the elf and Gimli the dwarf to Fangorn Forest. Then he fought in the battle at Helm's Deep and the Battle of the Pelennor Fields. After defeating Sauron's forces in Gondor, he led an army of Gondor and Rohan against the Black Gate of Mordor to distract Sauron's attention so that Frodo Baggins and Samwise Gamgee could have a chance to destroy the One Ring.


At the end of The Lord of the Rings, Aragorn was crowned King Elessar Telcontar (\\\"Elfstone Strider\\\") of Gondor. He married Elrond's daughter, Arwen, and assumed the Sceptre of Ann\\u00faminas as King of Arnor, uniting the two kingdoms for the first time since the reign of Isildur.

\"}, {\"type\": \"header\", \"value\": {\"header_text\": \"History\", \"size\": \"h2\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

The son of Arathorn II and his wife Gilraen, Aragorn was born on 1 March, T.A. 2931.[1] Through his ancestor Elendil (whom he closely resembled)[2] Aragorn was a descendant of the first king of N\\u00famenor, Elros Tar-Minyatur; the twin brother of Elrond.


When Aragorn was two years old, his father was killed while pursuing orcs. Aragorn was afterwards fostered in Rivendell by Elrond. At the bidding of Elrond, his lineage was kept secret, as Elrond feared he would be killed like his father and grandfather if his true identity as Isildur's heir became known. Aragorn was renamed Estel (\\\"hope\\\" in Sindarin) to hide his existence from Sauron and his servants. He was not told about his heritage until he came of age in 2951.[1]


Elrond revealed to Aragorn his true name and ancestry, and delivered to him the shards of Elendil's sword Narsil, and also the Ring of Barahir. He withheld the Sceptre of Ann\\u00faminas from him until he earned the right to possess it. Aragorn met and fell in love with Arwen, Elrond's daughter (whom he mistook for Tin\\u00faviel), when she returned from L\\u00f3rien, her mother's homeland.[1]


Aragorn thereafter assumed his role as the sixteenth Chieftain of the D\\u00fanedain, the Rangers of the North, and went into the wild, living with the remnants of his people, whose kingdom had been destroyed through civil and regional wars centuries before.[1]


Aragorn met Gandalf the Grey in 2956, and they became close friends.[1] The Rangers help to guard the Shire, inhabited by the diminutive, agrarian Hobbits. In the areas around the Shire and Bree he became known as \\\"Strider\\\".[3]


From 2957 to 2980, Aragorn undertook great journeys, serving in the armies of King Thengel of Rohan (King Th\\u00e9oden's father) and of Steward Ecthelion II of Gondor (father of Denethor). His tasks helped to raise morale in the West and to counter the growing threat of Sauron and his allies, and he acquired experience that he would later put to use in the War of the Ring. Aragorn served his lords during that time under the name Thorongil (Eagle of the Star). With a small squadron of ships from Gondor, he led an assault on Umbar in 2980, burning many of the Corsairs' ships and personally slaying their lord during the Battle of the Havens. After the victory at Umbar, \\\"Thorongil\\\" left the field, to the dismay of his men, and went East.[1]


Aragorn also travelled through the Dwarves' mines of Moria and to Rh\\u00fbn and Harad, where (in his own words) \\\"the stars are strange\\\".


In 2980, he visited L\\u00f3rien, and there again met Arwen. He gave her an heirloom of his House, the Ring of Barahir,[4] and, on the hill of Cerin Amroth, Arwen pledged her hand to him in marriage, renouncing her Elvish lineage and accepting mortality, the \\\"Gift of Men\\\". Elrond withheld from Aragorn permission to marry his daughter until such time as his foster son should be king of Gondor and Arnor reunited. To marry a mortal, Arwen would be required to choose mortality and thus eventually separate the immortal Elrond from his daughter; and Elrond feared that in the end Arwen might find the prospect of death too difficult to bear.[1]


Gandalf grew suspicious of the ring belonging to the hobbit Bilbo Baggins, which was later discovered to be Sauron's One Ring.[5] Gandalf asked Aragorn to track Gollum, who had previously possessed the Ring. This hunt led Aragorn across Rhovanion, and he finally captured Gollum in the Dead Marshes northwest of Mordor and brought him captive to King Thranduil\\u2019s halls in Mirkwood, where Gandalf questioned him.

\"}]", "first_published_at": "2016-10-24T15:19:40.837Z", "show_in_menus": false, "person_location_relationship": [{"person_page": 9, "pk": 1, "location": 8}], "title": "Aragorn", "person_status_relationship": [{"person_page": 9, "person_statuses": 1, "pk": 3}], "pk": 9, "content_type": 12, "go_live_at": null, "expired": false, "seo_title": "", "search_description": "", "latest_revision_created_at": "2017-01-10T17:49:28.120Z", "depth": 4, "live": true, "image": 2, "owner": 1, "numchild": 0, "locked": false, "person_skills_relationship": [{"person_page": 9, "sort_order": 0, "pk": 1, "skills": 6}], "path": "0001000100010001"}

This is some text on Arwen

{"expire_at": null, "slug": "arwen", "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/homepage/index-page/arwen/", "body": "[{\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Arwen Und\\u00f3miel is a fictional character in J. R. R. Tolkien's legendarium. She appears in his novel, The Lord of the Rings, usually published in three volumes. Arwen is one of the half-elven who lived during the Third Age.

\"}, {\"type\": \"header\", \"value\": {\"header_text\": \"Literature\", \"size\": \"h2\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Arwen was the youngest child of\\u00a0Elrond\\u00a0and\\u00a0Celebr\\u00edan. Her elder brothers were the twins\\u00a0Elladan and Elrohir. Her name\\u00a0Ar-wenmeans 'noble maiden'. She bore the\\u00a0sobriquet\\u00a0\\\"Evenstar\\\" (or Evening Star), as the most beautiful of the last generation of\\u00a0High Elves\\u00a0in Middle-earth.

As told in \\\"The Tale of Aragorn and Arwen\\\",[1]\\u00a0Aragorn\\u00a0in his twentieth year met Arwen for the first time in Rivendell, where he lived under Elrond's protection. Arwen, then over 2700 years old, had recently returned to her father's home after living for a while with her grandmother\\u00a0Lady Galadriel\\u00a0in\\u00a0L\\u00f3rien. Aragorn fell in love with Arwen at first sight. Some thirty years later, the two were reunited in L\\u00f3rien. Arwen reciprocated Aragorn's love, and on the mound of\\u00a0Cerin Amroth\\u00a0they committed themselves to marry each other.

Arwen first appears in the text of\\u00a0The Lord of the Rings\\u00a0in Rivendell shortly after\\u00a0Frodo Baggins\\u00a0awoke in the House of Elrond. She sat beside her father at the celebratory feast. When the\\u00a0Fellowship of the Ring\\u00a0came to Lothl\\u00f3rien, Aragorn remembered their earlier meeting and paused in reverence on Cerin Amroth.

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Shortly before Aragorn took the\\u00a0Paths of the Dead, he was joined by a group of\\u00a0D\\u00fanedain\\u00a0from the North, accompanied by Arwen's brothers, Elladan and Elrohir, who brought him as a gift from Arwen: a banner of black cloth. The banner was unfurled at the\\u00a0Battle of the Pelennor Fields\\u00a0to reveal the emblem of\\u00a0Elendil\\u00a0figured in\\u00a0mithril, gems, and gold; this became the first triumphant public announcement of the King's return.

\"}, {\"type\": \"blockquote\", \"value\": {\"attribute_group\": \"\", \"attribute_name\": \"Arwen\", \"text\": \"For I am the daughter of Elrond. I shall not go with him when he departs to the Havens: for mine is the choice of Luthien, and as she so have I chosen, both the sweet and the bitter.\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

After the War of the Ring, Aragorn became king of\\u00a0Arnor\\u00a0and\\u00a0Gondor. Arwen arrived at\\u00a0Minas Tirith, and they were married. She gave Frodo a necklace with a white stone, which would aid him when the darkness of his injuries troubled him.

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Arwen is a minor character in\\u00a0The Lord of the Rings, but she serves as inspiration and motivation for Aragorn, who must become King of both Arnor and Gondor before Elrond would allow her to marry him.

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

The Tale of Aragorn and Arwen\\u00a0relates that Aragorn and Arwen had a son,\\u00a0Eldarion, and at least two unnamed daughters. In\\u00a0F.A.\\u00a0121, one year after Aragorn's death, Arwen gave up her life, at the age of 2,901, at\\u00a0Cerin Amroth.

\"}, {\"type\": \"embed\", \"value\": \"https://youtu.be/N4I7myAG_mY\"}, {\"type\": \"header\", \"value\": {\"header_text\": \"Background\", \"size\": \"h2\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Through her father, Elrond, Arwen was the granddaughter of\\u00a0E\\u00e4rendil\\u00a0the Mariner (the second of the Half-elven), great-granddaughter of\\u00a0Tuor\\u00a0of\\u00a0Gondolin, and therefore a direct descendant of the ancient\\u00a0House of Hador. Through her great-grandmother,\\u00a0Idril, Arwen was also a descendant of King\\u00a0Turgon\\u00a0of the\\u00a0Noldor. Through her mother, she was the granddaughter of Lady\\u00a0Galadriel\\u00a0and the great-granddaughter of\\u00a0Finarfin.\\u00a0\\u00c9omer\\u00a0of\\u00a0Rohan\\u00a0said that the Lady Arwen was more fair than the Lady Galadriel of L\\u00f3rien, but\\u00a0Gimli son of Gl\\u00f3in\\u00a0thought differently. Through both of her parents Arwen was a direct descendant of the ancient Elven\\u00a0House of Finw\\u00eb. Furthermore, Arwen was a descendant of\\u00a0Beren\\u00a0and\\u00a0L\\u00fathien Tin\\u00faviel, whose\\u00a0story\\u00a0resembled hers. Indeed, Arwen was held to be the reappearance in likeness of her ancestress L\\u00fathien, fairest of all the\\u00a0Elves, who was called Nightingale (Tin\\u00faviel). Arwen was one of only three of the Eldar to wed a Man and was descended from the other two, Idril and L\\u00fathien.

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Arwen was a very distant relative of her husband Aragorn. Aragorn's ancestor,\\u00a0Elros Tar-Minyatur, the first\\u00a0King\\u00a0of\\u00a0N\\u00famenor, was her father Elrond's brother, who chose to live as a\\u00a0Man\\u00a0rather than as one of the Eldar. Arwen eventually became Queen of the\\u00a0Reunited Kingdom\\u00a0of Arnor and Gondor when she married Aragorn, who was of the line of the\\u00a0Kings of Arnor. By Arwen and Aragorn's marriage, the long-sundered lines of the Half-elven were joined. Their union also served to unite and preserve the bloodlines of the Three Kings of the High Elves (Ingw\\u00eb,\\u00a0Finw\\u00eb, and the brothers\\u00a0Olw\\u00eb\\u00a0and\\u00a0Elw\\u00eb) as well as the only line with\\u00a0Maiarin\\u00a0blood through Arwen's great-great-great grandmother,\\u00a0Melian, Queen of\\u00a0Doriath, and also on Aragorn's side, through the line of kings of Arnor and N\\u00famenor to Elros, Elrond's brother, whose great-great-grandmother was also Melian.

\"}]", "first_published_at": "2017-01-09T10:35:32.077Z", "show_in_menus": false, "person_location_relationship": [{"person_page": 11, "pk": 2, "location": 19}], "title": "Arwen", "person_status_relationship": [{"person_page": 11, "person_statuses": 2, "pk": 2}], "pk": 11, "content_type": 12, "go_live_at": null, "expired": false, "seo_title": "", "search_description": "", "latest_revision_created_at": "2017-01-12T21:12:08.466Z", "depth": 4, "live": true, "image": 3, "owner": 1, "numchild": 0, "locked": false, "person_skills_relationship": [{"person_page": 11, "sort_order": 0, "pk": 2, "skills": 10}, {"person_page": 11, "sort_order": 1, "pk": 5, "skills": 21}, {"person_page": 11, "sort_order": 2, "pk": 6, "skills": 20}], "path": "0001000100010002"}

{"expire_at": null, "slug": "boromir", "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/homepage/index-page/boromir/", "body": "[{\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Boromir\\u00a0is a character in\\u00a0J. R. R. Tolkien's\\u00a0legendarium. He appears in the first two volumes of\\u00a0The Lord of the Rings\\u00a0(The Fellowship of the Ring\\u00a0and\\u00a0The Two Towers), and is mentioned in the last volume,\\u00a0The Return of the King. He is the heir of\\u00a0Denethor II\\u00a0(the 26th\\u00a0Ruling Stewardof\\u00a0Gondor) and the elder brother of\\u00a0Faramir. In the course of the story Boromir joins the\\u00a0Fellowship of the Ring.

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Boromir is portrayed as a noble character who believes passionately in the greatness of his kingdom, who would have defended its people to the last. Boromir's great stamina and physical strength, together with a forceful and commanding personality, made him a widely admired commander in Gondor's army: he was made Captain of the White Tower, and quickly became Captain-General, also bearing the title High Warden of the White Tower. He was also heir apparent to the Stewardship. Boromir led many successful forays against\\u00a0Sauron's forces, prior to his journey north to\\u00a0Rivendell, which brought him great esteem in the eyes of his father, Denethor.

\"}, {\"type\": \"header\", \"value\": {\"header_text\": \"Literature\", \"size\": \"h2\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Boromir, as a character, is portrayed as having been born in the year 2978 of the\\u00a0Third Age\\u00a0to\\u00a0Denethor II\\u00a0and\\u00a0Finduilas, daughter of Adrahil of\\u00a0Dol Amroth. His younger brother,\\u00a0Faramir, was born in the year\\u00a0T.A.\\u00a02983. The following year, Denethor became Steward of Gondor, succeeding his father,\\u00a0Ecthelion II. Boromir simultaneously became heir apparent, inheriting the\\u00a0Horn of Gondor.

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Boromir was named after the son of\\u00a0Denethor I, who was Steward around 500 years before the War of the Ring. The\\u00a0first Boromir\\u00a0was known as a great captain who cleared\\u00a0Ithilien\\u00a0of orcs of\\u00a0Mordor\\u00a0and was feared even by the\\u00a0Witch-king\\u00a0himself. Thus there were high expectations for Boromir the son of Denethor II.

\"}, {\"type\": \"blockquote\", \"value\": {\"attribute_group\": \"\", \"attribute_name\": \"Boromir\", \"text\": \"It is a strange fate that we should suffer so much fear and doubt over so small a thing. Such a little thing.\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

When Boromir's mother Finduilas died (T.A.\\u00a02988), he was aged only 10. Denethor became sombre, cold and detached from his family. As their father withdrew, the relationship between Faramir and Boromir grew closer and greater in love. Denethor always favoured Boromir over Faramir\\u2014Denethor loved Boromir \\\"too much, perhaps; the more so because they were unlike\\\"[1]\\u2014but this caused no rivalry between the two brothers. Boromir always protected and helped Faramir. Boromir was judged to be the more daring one, as well as the more fearless.

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

In response to prophetic dreams that came to Faramir and later to himself, Boromir claimed the quest of riding to\\u00a0Rivendell\\u00a0from\\u00a0Minas Tirith\\u00a0in\\u00a0T.A.\\u00a03018. His journey lasted a hundred and eleven days, and he travelled through \\\"roads forgotten\\\" to reach Rivendell, though, as he said, \\\"few knew where it lay\\\".[2]\\u00a0Boromir lost his horse halfway along, while crossing the\\u00a0Greyfloodat the ruined city of\\u00a0Tharbad\\u00a0where the bridge was broken. He had to travel the remaining way on foot[3]\\u00a0and barely arrived in time for the Council of Elrond. (Tolkien wrote of Boromir's journey that \\\"the courage and hardihood required is not fully recognized in the narrative\\\".)[4]

\"}]", "first_published_at": "2017-01-09T10:58:20.579Z", "show_in_menus": false, "person_location_relationship": [{"person_page": 13, "pk": 4, "location": 8}], "title": "Boromir", "person_status_relationship": [{"person_page": 13, "person_statuses": 1, "pk": 1}], "pk": 13, "content_type": 12, "go_live_at": null, "expired": false, "seo_title": "", "search_description": "", "latest_revision_created_at": "2017-01-10T17:49:07Z", "depth": 4, "live": true, "image": 6, "owner": 1, "numchild": 0, "locked": false, "person_skills_relationship": [{"person_page": 13, "sort_order": 0, "pk": null, "skills": 21}, {"person_page": 13, "sort_order": 1, "pk": null, "skills": 26}, {"person_page": 13, "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "skills": 23}], "path": "0001000100010003"}

{"expire_at": null, "slug": "saruman", "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/homepage/index-page/saruman/", "body": "[{\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Saruman the White\\u00a0is a fictional character and a major antagonist in\\u00a0J. R. R. Tolkien's fantasy novel\\u00a0The Lord of the Rings. He is leader of the\\u00a0Istari, wizards sent to\\u00a0Middle-earth\\u00a0in human form by the godlike\\u00a0Valar\\u00a0to challenge\\u00a0Sauron, the main antagonist of the novel, but eventually he desires Sauron's power for himself and tries to take over Middle-earth by force. His schemes feature prominently in the second volume,\\u00a0The Two Towers, and at the end of the third volume,\\u00a0The Return of the King. His earlier history is given briefly in the posthumously published\\u00a0The Silmarillion\\u00a0and\\u00a0Unfinished Tales.

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Saruman is one of several characters in the book illustrating the corruption of power; his desire for knowledge and order leads to his fall, and he rejects the chance of redemption when it is offered. The name\\u00a0Saruman\\u00a0[\\u02c8saruman]\\u00a0means \\\"man of skill\\\" in the\\u00a0Mercian dialect\\u00a0of\\u00a0Anglo-Saxon;[1]\\u00a0he serves as an example of technology and modernity being overthrown by forces more in tune with nature. Saruman is represented by a white hand.

\"}, {\"type\": \"header\", \"value\": {\"header_text\": \"Characterisation\", \"size\": \"h2\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Tolkien described Saruman at the time of\\u00a0The Lord of the Rings\\u00a0as having a long face and a high forehead, \\\"...he had deep darkling eyes ... His hair and beard were white, but strands of black still showed around his lips and ears.\\\"[24]\\u00a0His hair is elsewhere described as having been black when he first arrived in Middle-earth. He is referred to as 'Saruman the White' and is said to have originally worn white robes, but on his first entry in\\u00a0The Fellowship of the Ring\\u00a0they instead appear to be \\\"woven from all colours [, they] shimmered and changed hue so that the eye was bewildered\\\" and he names himself 'Saruman of Many Colours'.[25]

\"}, {\"type\": \"embed\", \"value\": \"https://youtu.be/TQq4LjSF2rc\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

The power of Saruman's voice is noted throughout the book. Jonathan Evans calls the characterization of Saruman in the chapter\\u00a0The Voice of Saruman\\u00a0a \\\"tour de force\\\".[20]\\u00a0Roger Sale\\u00a0says of the same chapter that \\\"Tolkien valiantly tried to do something worth doing which he simply cannot bring off.\\\"[26]\\u00a0Tom Shippey\\u00a0writes that \\\"Saruman talks like a politician ... No other character in Middle-earth has Saruman's trick of balancing phrases against each other so that incompatibles are resolved, and none comes out with words as empty as 'deploring', 'ultimate', worst of all, 'real'. What is 'real change'?\\\"[27]Shippey contrasts this modern speech pattern with the archaic stoicism and directness that Tolkien employs for other characters such as the\\u00a0Dwarven\\u00a0King\\u00a0D\\u00e1in, which Shippey believes represent Tolkien's view of heroism in the mould of\\u00a0Beowulf.[27]

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

After the defeat of his armies, having been caught in the betrayal of Sauron, Saruman is offered refuge by Gandalf, in return for his aid, but having chosen his path, is unable to turn from it.[28]\\u00a0Evans has compared the character of Saruman to that of\\u00a0Satan\\u00a0in\\u00a0John Milton's\\u00a0Paradise Lost\\u00a0in his use of rhetoric and in this final refusal of redemption, \\\"conquered by pride and hatred\\\".[20]

\"}]", "first_published_at": null, "show_in_menus": false, "person_location_relationship": [{"person_page": 27, "pk": 5, "location": 14}], "title": "Saruman", "person_status_relationship": [{"person_page": 27, "person_statuses": 3, "pk": 4}], "pk": 27, "content_type": 12, "go_live_at": null, "expired": false, "seo_title": "", "search_description": "", "latest_revision_created_at": null, "depth": 4, "live": true, "image": 18, "owner": 1, "numchild": 0, "locked": false, "person_skills_relationship": [{"person_page": 27, "sort_order": 0, "pk": 10, "skills": 6}, {"person_page": 27, "sort_order": 1, "pk": 11, "skills": 24}], "path": "0001000100010004"}

{"expire_at": null, "slug": "\u00e9owyn", "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/homepage/index-page/\u00e9owyn/", "body": "[{\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

\\u00c9owyn is a fictional character in Tolkien's legendarium who appears in his most famous work, The Lord of the Rings. She is a noblewoman of Rohan who is described as a shieldmaiden.

\"}, {\"type\": \"header\", \"value\": {\"header_text\": \"Literature\", \"size\": \"h2\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

In\\u00a0The Two Towers, \\u00c9owyn, a daughter of the\\u00a0House of Eorl\\u00a0and the goddaughter of King\\u00a0Th\\u00e9oden\\u00a0of Rohan, is introduced in Meduseld, the king's hall at Edoras.[1]\\u00a0She was the daughter of Th\\u00e9odwyn (Th\\u00e9oden's sister) and \\u00c9omund and the sister of\\u00a0\\u00c9omer. When she was only seven years old, her father was killed fighting\\u00a0orcs\\u00a0and her mother died of grief. \\u00c9owyn and \\u00c9omer were raised in her uncle's household as if they were his own children.

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Tolkien writes that she longed to win renown in battle\\u2014especially since she was royal\\u2014but being female, her duties were reckoned to be at Edoras.[2]\\u00a0When Th\\u00e9oden's mind was poisoned by his adviser\\u00a0Gr\\u00edma Wormtongue, \\u00c9owyn was obliged to care for her uncle, and his deterioration pained her deeply. To make matters worse, she was constantly harassed by Gr\\u00edma, who lusted after her. However, when\\u00a0Gandalf\\u00a0arrived, he freed Th\\u00e9oden from Wormtongue's influence.

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

\\u00c9owyn fell in love with\\u00a0Aragorn, but it soon became clear that he could not return her love although he did not mention his betrothal to\\u00a0Arwen, except by indirect allusion, and would not allow her to join him in going to war.[3]\\u00a0As Aragorn pointed out,[3]\\u00a0her duty was with her people; she had to shoulder the responsibility of ruling Rohan in Th\\u00e9oden's stead when the war-host of Rohan went to war,[1]\\u00a0a duty he deemed no less valiant.[3]\\u00a0Likening her situation to a \\\"cage\\\", \\u00c9owyn said she feared \\\"[t]o stay behind bars, until use and old age accept them, and all chance of great deeds is gone beyond recall or desire.\\\"[3]

\"}, {\"type\": \"blockquote\", \"value\": {\"attribute_group\": \"\", \"attribute_name\": \"Aragorn\", \"text\": \"But who knows what she spoke to the darkness, alone, in the bitter watches of the night, when all her life seemed shrinking, and the walls of her bower closing in about her, a hutch to trammel some wild thing in?\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"In\\u00a0The Return of the King

The Return of the King

, she disguised herself as a man and under the alias of\\u00a0Dernhelm\\u00a0(from Old English\\u00a0dern\\u00a0meaning \\\"secret, concealed\\\"), and she traveled with the Riders of Rohan to the\\u00a0Battle of the Pelennor Fields\\u00a0outside the White City of\\u00a0Minas Tirith\\u00a0in\\u00a0Gondor, carrying with her\\u00a0Meriadoc Brandybuck, who had also been ordered to remain behind, on her horse Windfola.\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

During the battle of the Pelennor Fields, she confronted the\\u00a0Witch-king of Angmar, Lord of the\\u00a0Nazg\\u00fbl, after Th\\u00e9oden was injured. The Witch-king threatened to \\\"bear [her] away to the houses of lamentation, beyond all darkness, where [her] flesh shall be devoured, and [her] shriveled mind be left naked to the Lidless Eye.\\\"[4]\\u00a0The Witch-king further boasted that \\\"[n]o living man may hinder me,\\\"[4]\\u00a0referring to the 1,000-year-old\\u00a0prophecy\\u00a0by the\\u00a0Elf-lord\\u00a0Glorfindel, foretelling that the Witch-king would not fall \\\"by the hand of man\\\".[5]\\u00a0\\u00c9owyn then removed her helmet and declared.

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

But no living man am I! You look upon a woman. \\u00c9owyn I am, \\u00c9omund\\u2019s daughter. You stand between me and my lord and kin. Begone, if you be not deathless! For living or dark undead, I will smite you, if you touch him.[4]

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

The Witch-king attacked \\u00c9owyn with his\\u00a0steed, but she slew it with her sword. He then shattered her shield and broke her shield-arm with his mace, but was distracted by Merry, who stabbed him behind the knee with a\\u00a0barrow-blade. \\u00c9owyn seized the opportunity to strike the Witch-king with a killing thrust \\\"between crown and mantle\\\".[4]\\u00a0Then, as her sword shattered, his withering form collapsed and he vanished with a final cry of anguish.

\"}]", "first_published_at": null, "show_in_menus": false, "person_location_relationship": [{"person_page": 28, "pk": 6, "location": 15}], "title": "\u00c9owyn", "person_status_relationship": [{"person_page": 28, "person_statuses": 1, "pk": 5}], "pk": 28, "content_type": 12, "go_live_at": null, "expired": false, "seo_title": "", "search_description": "", "latest_revision_created_at": null, "depth": 4, "live": true, "image": 19, "owner": 1, "numchild": 0, "locked": false, "person_skills_relationship": [{"person_page": 28, "sort_order": 0, "pk": 12, "skills": 26}, {"person_page": 28, "sort_order": 1, "pk": 13, "skills": 21}, {"person_page": 28, "sort_order": 2, "pk": 14, "skills": 24}, {"person_page": 28, "sort_order": 3, "pk": 15, "skills": 22}], "path": "0001000100010005"}

{"expire_at": null, "slug": "th\u00e9oden", "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/homepage/index-page/th\u00e9oden/", "body": "[{\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Th\\u00e9oden\\u00a0is a fictional character in\\u00a0J. R. R. Tolkien's\\u00a0fantasy\\u00a0novel,\\u00a0The Lord of the Rings. The King of\\u00a0Rohan, he appears as a major supporting character in\\u00a0The Two Towers\\u00a0and\\u00a0The Return of the King.

\"}, {\"type\": \"header\", \"value\": {\"header_text\": \"Appearances\", \"size\": \"h2\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Th\\u00e9oden is introduced in\\u00a0The Two Towers, the second volume of\\u00a0The Lord of the Rings, as the King of\\u00a0Rohan. By the time of the\\u00a0War of the Ring, Th\\u00e9oden had grown weak with age, and was largely controlled by his chief advisor\\u00a0Gr\\u00edma\\u00a0(or\\u00a0Wormtongue\\u00a0as most others in the\\u00a0Riddermark\\u00a0called him), who was secretly in the employ of the corrupt wizard\\u00a0Saruman. In\\u00a0Unfinished Tales, it is implied that the failure of the king's health was \\\"...induced or increased by subtle poisons, administered by Gr\\u00edma\\\".[1]\\u00a0As Th\\u00e9oden sat powerless, Rohan was troubled by\\u00a0Orcs\\u00a0and\\u00a0Dunlendings, who operated under the\\u00a0will\\u00a0of Saruman, ruling from\\u00a0Isengard.

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

When his son\\u00a0Th\\u00e9odred\\u00a0was mortally wounded at a\\u00a0battle at the Fords of Isen, Th\\u00e9oden's nephew\\u00a0\\u00c9omer\\u00a0became his heir. However, \\u00c9omer was out of favour with Wormtongue, who eventually had him arrested.

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

When\\u00a0Gandalf the White\\u00a0and\\u00a0Aragorn, along with Legolas and Gimli, appeared before him in\\u00a0The Two Towers, Th\\u00e9oden initially rebuffed the\\u00a0wizard's advice to oppose Saruman. When Gandalf revealed Wormtongue for what he was, however, Th\\u00e9oden returned to his senses. He restored his nephew, took up his sword\\u00a0Herugrim, and in spite of his age, led the Riders of Rohan into the\\u00a0Battle of the Hornburg. After this he became known as Th\\u00e9oden Ednew, the Renewed.

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

In\\u00a0The Return of the King, Th\\u00e9oden led the Rohirrim to the aid of\\u00a0Gondor\\u00a0at the\\u00a0Battle of the Pelennor Fields. In that battle he routed the\\u00a0Harad\\u00a0cavalry, personally killing their chieftain and banner-bearer in the process. He challenged the\\u00a0Witch-king of Angmar, the leader of the\\u00a0Nazg\\u00fbl, and was mortally wounded when his horse\\u00a0Snowmane\\u00a0fell upon him. He was avenged by his niece\\u00a0\\u00c9owyn\\u00a0and the\\u00a0hobbit\\u00a0Meriadoc \\\"Merry\\\" Brandybuck, who had ridden to war in secret; together, they destroyed the Witch-king. Before mustering the Rohirrim to ride to Gondor's aid, Th\\u00e9oden enlisted Merry into his army, but did not let the hobbit ride into\\u00a0battle at Pelennor. In his last moments, he bid farewell to Merry and appointed \\u00c9omer the next king.

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Th\\u00e9oden's body lay in\\u00a0Minas Tirith\\u00a0until it was buried in Rohan after the defeat of\\u00a0Sauron. He was the last of the Second Line of the kings, judging from direct descent from\\u00a0Eorl the Young.

\"}]", "first_published_at": null, "show_in_menus": false, "person_location_relationship": [{"person_page": 29, "pk": 7, "location": 16}], "title": "Th\u00e9oden", "person_status_relationship": [{"person_page": 29, "person_statuses": 1, "pk": 6}], "pk": 29, "content_type": 12, "go_live_at": null, "expired": false, "seo_title": "", "search_description": "", "latest_revision_created_at": null, "depth": 4, "live": true, "image": 20, "owner": 1, "numchild": 0, "locked": false, "person_skills_relationship": [{"person_page": 29, "sort_order": 0, "pk": 16, "skills": 10}, {"person_page": 29, "sort_order": 1, "pk": 17, "skills": 21}], "path": "0001000100010006"}

{"expire_at": null, "slug": "treebeard", "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/homepage/index-page/treebeard/", "body": "[{\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Treebeard\\u00a0(Sindarin:\\u00a0Fangorn) is a fictional character from\\u00a0J. R. R. Tolkien's\\u00a0Middle-earth\\u00a0fantasy writings. The eldest of the species of\\u00a0Ents, he is said to live in the ancient\\u00a0Forest of Fangorn\\u00a0and stands fourteen feet (4 m) in height. He is treelike in appearance, with leafy hair and a rigid structure.[1]\\u00a0His home of Fangorn Forest lies next to\\u00a0Isengard, where\\u00a0Saruman the White\\u00a0resides. Treebeard's motto is \\\"Do not be hasty.\\\"[1]

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

In\\u00a0The Two Towers\\u00a0he meets with\\u00a0Meriadoc Brandybuck\\u00a0and\\u00a0Peregrin Took, two\\u00a0Hobbits\\u00a0of\\u00a0the Shire\\u00a0known also as Merry and Pippin.[1]\\u00a0Treebeard is known to have a strong hatred of\\u00a0Orcs, and, after Saruman's betrayal of the Ents, of Saruman as well.[1][2]\\u00a0During his initial encounter with the two hobbits, he is so agitated that he misidentifies them as orc spies. He then carries them to the white wizard.

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Spirits were sent by\\u00a0Eru Il\\u00favatar\\u00a0to inhabit the\\u00a0trees, which the\\u00a0Vala\\u00a0Yavanna\\u00a0had created along with other plants or\\u00a0olvar. The Vala longed for their protection since\\u00a0Morgoth\\u00a0or\\u00a0Melkor\\u00a0was destroying the trees and olvar, which could not defend themselves from him. The Ents were created by Il\\u00favatar at the behest of Yavanna as the\\u00a0Shepherds of the Forest\\u00a0or\\u00a0Tree-herders.\\u00a0Entwives\\u00a0were also created for the Ents, but, in the\\u00a0Second Age, were driven out by\\u00a0Sauron.[1][2][3]

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Treebeard is the oldest of three remaining original Ents.[1][4]\\u00a0He is said to have once roamed all of the forests in Middle-earth, which included the\\u00a0Misty Mountains,\\u00a0Mirkwood,\\u00a0Mordor, and the Blue Mountains. After the loss of the Entwives by the end of the\\u00a0Third Age, he and the remaining Ents dwelt in the Forest of Fangorn. This led the remaining Ents into isolation and all information from the outside world was cut off.[1]\\u00a0The arrival of Merry and Pippin shifted Treebeard's attention to take action against Saruman for hacking down his trees. He led the Ents to war against Saruman and his Orcs. Treebeard later realised that while Saruman had learned much from him, the Wizard had shared no useful information of his own.[1]

\"}, {\"type\": \"blockquote\", \"value\": {\"attribute_group\": \"\", \"attribute_name\": \"JRR Tolkien\", \"text\": \"A large Man-like figure, at least fourteen foot high, very sturdy, with a tall head, and hardly any neck. Whether it was clad in stuff like green and grey bark, or whether that was its hide, was difficult to say. Arms, at a short distance from the trunk, were not wrinkled, but covered with a brown smooth skin. The large feet had seven toes each. Grey beard, deep brown eyes, shot with a green light.\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Treebeard had been friends with Saruman. It is described in\\u00a0The Two Towers\\u00a0that Saruman visited Treebeard in Fangorn Forest and had talked with him on various subjects of concern. Saruman gathered information from Treebeard about the Forest of Fangorn; its intertwining paths were of particular concern to him.[1]

\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

After Merry and Pippin's meeting with Treebeard, Treebeard called an\\u00a0Entmoot, which lasted three days, to decide to call an attack on Isengard and Saruman.[1][2][4]\\u00a0Since\\u00a0Leaflock\\u00a0and\\u00a0Skinbark\\u00a0were the oldest of the Ents along with Treebeard, they refused to fight, however, Treebeard thought he was going to his doom during \\\"the last march of the Ents.\\\"[1][4]\\u00a0Treebeard hoped that some of the younger Ents would come instead of just the two, and, during the night he spread the word. They later launched an assault on Isengard.[1][2][4]

\"}, {\"type\": \"embed\", \"value\": \"https://youtu.be/BbV2Hr0qRdo\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"
