", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"header_text": "First Age", "size": "h3"}, "type": "header"}, {"value": "

In the terminology of Tolkien's\u00a0invented language\u00a0of\u00a0Quenya, these angelic spirits were called\u00a0Ainur. Those who entered the physical world were called\u00a0Valar, especially the most powerful ones. The (mostly) lesser beings who entered the world, of whom Sauron was one, were called\u00a0Maiar. In Tolkien's letters, the author noted that Sauron \"was of course a 'divine' person (in the terms of this mythology; a lesser member of the race of Valar)\".[7]\u00a0Tolkien noted that he was of a \"far higher order\" than the Maiar who later came to Middle-earth as the\u00a0Wizards\u00a0Gandalf\u00a0and\u00a0Saruman.[8]\u00a0As created by Eru, the Ainur were all good and uncorrupt, as\u00a0Elrond\u00a0stated in\u00a0The Lord of the Rings: \"Nothing is evil in the beginning. Even Sauron was not so.\"[9]

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"header_text": "Sauron's fall", "size": "h4"}, "type": "header"}, {"value": "

Melkor opposed the other Valar, who remained faithful to Eru and tried to carry out the Creator's designs. Within the larger universe, they eventually focused on developing the world of\u00a0Arda\u00a0(Earth, or the entire solar system). Around this time, Sauron fell victim to Melkor's corrupting influence: \"In the beginning of Arda, Melkor seduced him to his allegiance.\"[17]

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

As for Sauron's motives, Tolkien noted that \"it had been his virtue (and therefore also the cause of his fall ...) that he loved order and coordination, and disliked all confusion and wasteful friction\". Thus \"it was the apparent will and power of Melkor to effect his designs quickly and masterfully that had first attracted Sauron to him\".[18]

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

For a while, Sauron apparently kept up the pretence that he was a faithful servant of the Valar, all the while feeding Melkor information about their doings. Thus, when the Valar made\u00a0Almaren\u00a0as their first physical abode in the world, \"Melkor knew of all that was done; for even then he had secret friends and spies among the Maiar whom he had converted to his cause, and of these the chief, as after became known, was Sauron.\"[14]

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

Melkor soon destroyed Almaren, and the Valar established a new abode in the Uttermost West: the Blessed Realm of\u00a0Valinor. They still did not perceive Sauron's treachery, for he too became \"a being of Valinor\".[19]

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

At some point, Sauron left the Blessed Realm and went to\u00a0Middle-earth, the central continent of Arda, where Melkor had established his stronghold. In one text, Tolkien wrote of Sauron that \"in Valinor he had dwelt among the people of the gods, but there Morgoth had drawn him to evil and to his service\".[20]\u00a0Sauron deserted his service to the Valar and openly joined their great enemy: \"Because of his admiration of Strength he had become a follower of Morgoth and fell with him down into the depths of evil.\"[8]

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"header_text": "The Lieutenant of Melkor", "size": "h4"}, "type": "header"}, {"value": "

After joining his new master in Middle-earth, Sauron proved to be a devoted and capable servant: \"While Morgoth still stood, Sauron did not seek his own supremacy, but worked and schemed for another, desiring the triumph of Melkor, whom in the beginning he had adored. He thus was often able to achieve things, first conceived by Melkor, which his master did not or could not complete in the furious haste of his malice.\"[21]\u00a0\"In all the deeds of Melkor the Morgoth upon Arda, in his vast works and in the deceits of his cunning, Sauron had a part.\"[22]

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

In chapter three of\u00a0The Silmarillion, Tolkien writes that by the time the\u00a0Elves\u00a0awoke in the world, Sauron had become Melkor's lieutenant and was given command over the newly built stronghold of\u00a0Angband. To protect the Elves, the Valar made war on Melkor and captured him, but could not find Sauron.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

Thus, \"when Melkor was made captive, Sauron escaped and lay hid in Middle-earth; and it can in this way be understood how the breeding of the\u00a0Orcs\u00a0(no doubt already begun) went on with increasing speed\". In the Blessed Realm, Melkor feigned reform, but eventually escaped back to Middle-earth, holding the\u00a0Silmarils\u00a0of\u00a0F\u00ebanor. By then, Sauron had \"secretly repaired Angband for the help of his Master when he returned; and there the dark places underground were already manned with hosts of the Orcs before Melkor came back at last, as Morgoth the Black Enemy\".[23]

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

Shortly after the return of Morgoth, the\u00a0Noldorin\u00a0Elves also left the\u00a0Blessed Realm of Valinor\u00a0in the Uttermost West, against the counsel of the Valar, to wage war on Morgoth, who had stolen the Silmarils. In that war, Sauron served as Morgoth's chief lieutenant, surpassing all others in rank, such as\u00a0Gothmog, the Lord of\u00a0Balrogs. Known as\u00a0Gorthaur the Cruel, Sauron was at that time a master of illusions and\u00a0shapeshifting;\u00a0werewolves\u00a0and vampires were his servants, chief among them\u00a0Draugluin, Father of Werewolves, and his vampire herald\u00a0Thuringwethil.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

When Morgoth left Angband to corrupt the newly discovered\u00a0Men, Sauron directed the war against the Elves. He conquered the Elvish island of Tol Sirion and its watchtower\u00a0Minas Tirith, so that it became known as\u00a0Tol-in-Gaurhoth,\u00a0the Isle of Werewolves.

", "type": "paragraph"}]

[{"value": "

Peregrin Took, more commonly known as\u00a0Pippin, is a\u00a0fictional character\u00a0from\u00a0J. R. R. Tolkien's fantasy novel\u00a0The Lord of the Rings. Pippin is introduced as a young\u00a0Hobbit, and plays a major role as one of the companions of\u00a0Frodo Baggins, in his quest to destroy the\u00a0One Ring. Pippin is a member of the\u00a0Fellowship of the Ring.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"header_text": "Overview", "size": "h2"}, "type": "header"}, {"value": "

Peregrin was the only son and heir of Paladin Took II, the\u00a0Thain\u00a0of\u00a0the Shire. His best friend\u00a0Meriadoc Brandybuck, more commonly known as Merry, was his cousin; another good friend was\u00a0Frodo Baggins.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

'Peregrin' means 'traveller in strange countries'.[1]\u00a0Pippin indeed saw much more of Middle-earth than most Hobbits: he journeyed with\u00a0Frodo\u00a0and the\u00a0Fellowship of the Ring, and fought in the\u00a0War of the Ring. Late in life he travelled again to the kingdoms of\u00a0Rohan\u00a0and\u00a0Gondor.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

Pippin's hair colour is mentioned as \"almost golden\" in\u00a0The History of Middle-earth, vol. IX,\u00a0Sauron Defeated, through the eyes of Pippin Gamgee.[2]\u00a0In the later drafts of this same section Tolkien omitted this statement, leaving the reader to envisage Pippin's appearance.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"header_text": "The Great Years", "size": "h2"}, "type": "header"}, {"value": "

Pippin was the youngest of the four Hobbits who set out from the Shire and the only one who had not yet reached his 'coming of age' at age 33. He was therefore said to be still in his 'tweens' (twenties). He was 28 at the time, while Merry, the next youngest, was 36. At\u00a0Rivendell,\u00a0Elrond\u00a0almost denied Pippin the chance to accompany Frodo, intending to send Pippin and Merry as messengers back to the Shire.\u00a0Gandalf, however, supported his and Merry's claims of friendship and loyalty, and the\u00a0Council of Elrond\u00a0ultimately chose them as the last two members of the\u00a0Fellowship.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "https://youtu.be/5cZ4ABUo6TU", "type": "embed"}, {"value": "

After remaining with the Fellowship until its breaking at\u00a0Amon Hen, Pippin was captured along with Merry by an\u00a0Orc-band, which included some of\u00a0Saruman's\u00a0Uruk-hai. While held captive by the Orcs, he purposefully dropped his elven brooch (a gift from\u00a0L\u00f3rien) as a sign for\u00a0Aragorn,\u00a0Legolas, and\u00a0Gimli, who were in pursuit. During a skirmish among his captors, Pippin managed to cut his bonds using a sword held fast by a dead Uruk. In\u00a0Rohan, Pippin and Merry managed to escape when the Orcs were attacked by a company of\u00a0Rohirrim, the local people. Upon their escape, he and Merry befriended\u00a0Treebeard, leader of the\u00a0Ents. They roused the other Ents to fight against Saruman, and they attacked his stronghold of\u00a0Isengard, partially crippling his power. Due to a special \"Ent-draught\" that Treebeard made him and Merry drink, Pippin and his cousin became the tallest Hobbits in history, at four and a half feet, surpassing Pippin's ancestor,\u00a0Bullroarer Took, who was four feet and five inches tall.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

Pippin picked up the\u00a0palant\u00edr\u00a0of\u00a0Orthanc\u00a0after\u00a0Gr\u00edma Wormtongue\u00a0threw it at them. Later, obsessed by the mysterious stone, Pippin took it out of Gandalf's hands while the\u00a0wizard\u00a0slept, putting a rock in its place. Looking into the stone, he had a terrifying encounter with\u00a0Sauron\u00a0himself. In fact, Pippin is the only character in the book who is shown to speak directly to Sauron. To keep Pippin safe from Sauron's forces, Gandalf brought him to the city of\u00a0Minas Tirith, separating him from his friends.

", "type": "paragraph"}]

[{"value": "

Frodo Baggins\u00a0is a\u00a0fictional character\u00a0in\u00a0J. R. R. Tolkien's legendarium, and the main protagonist of\u00a0The Lord of the Rings. Frodo is a\u00a0hobbit\u00a0of\u00a0the Shire\u00a0who inherits the\u00a0One Ring\u00a0from his cousin\u00a0Bilbo Baggins\u00a0and undertakes the quest to destroy it in the fires of\u00a0Mount Doom. He is also mentioned in Tolkien's posthumously published works,\u00a0The Silmarillion\u00a0and\u00a0Unfinished Tales.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"header_text": "Concept and creation", "size": "h2"}, "type": "header"}, {"value": "

Frodo did not appear until the third draft of\u00a0A Long-Expected Party\u00a0(the first chapter of\u00a0The Lord of the Rings), when he was named Bingo (after a family of toy\u00a0koala\u00a0owned by Tolkien's children), son of Bilbo Baggins and Primula Brandybuck.[1]\u00a0In the fourth draft, he was renamed Bingo Bolger-Baggins, son of Rollo Bolger and Primula Brandybuck.[2]\u00a0Tolkien did not change the name to Frodo until the third phase of writing, when much of the narrative, as far as the hobbits' arrival in\u00a0Rivendell, had already taken shape.[3]\u00a0Prior to this, the name \"Frodo\" had been used for the character who eventually became\u00a0Peregrin Took.[4]

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"header_text": "The Fellowship of the Ring", "size": "h2"}, "type": "header"}, {"value": "

The Fellowship of the Ring\u00a0opens as Frodo came of age (at 33 years old) and Bilbo left\u00a0the Shire\u00a0for good on his one hundred and eleventh birthday. Frodo inherited\u00a0Bag End\u00a0and\u00a0Bilbo's ring, which were both introduced in\u00a0The Hobbit.\u00a0Gandalf, at this time, was not certain about the origin of the Ring, so he warned Frodo to avoid using it and to keep it secret. Frodo kept the Ring hidden for 17 years, resulting in it giving him the same longevity of Bilbo, until Gandalf returned to tell him that it was the One Ring of the Dark Lord\u00a0Sauron, who desired to use it to conquer\u00a0Middle-earth.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

Realizing that he was a danger to the Shire as long as he remained there with the Ring, Frodo decided to leave home and take the Ring to\u00a0Rivendell, home of\u00a0Elrond, a mighty\u00a0Elf\u00a0lord. He left the Shire with three companions: his gardener\u00a0Samwise Gamgee\u00a0and his cousins\u00a0Meriadoc Brandybuck\u00a0and\u00a0Peregrin Took. They escaped just in time, for Sauron's most powerful servants, the Nine\u00a0Nazg\u00fbl, had entered the Shire as Black Riders, looking for Bilbo and the Ring. They followed Frodo's trail across the Shire and nearly intercepted him.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

Frodo and his companions escaped the Black Riders by travelling through the\u00a0Old Forest, but they were misled by the magic of\u00a0Old Man Willow\u00a0until they were rescued by\u00a0Tom Bombadil, who gave them shelter and guided them on their way. After leaving Bombadil, they were caught in fog on the\u00a0Barrow Downs\u00a0by\u00a0Barrow-wights\u00a0and were entranced under a spell. Frodo broke loose from the spell, attacked the barrow-wight and summoned Tom Bombadil, who again rescued the hobbits and set them on their way.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

At the\u00a0Prancing Pony, an inn in the village of\u00a0Bree, Frodo received a delayed\u00a0letter from Gandalf, and met\u00a0Aragorn, also called Strider, a\u00a0Ranger of the North. Strider became the hobbits' guide while journeying through the wilderness towards Rivendell. The One Ring slipped onto Frodo's finger inadvertently in the\u00a0Prancing Pony's common room, turning Frodo invisible. This attracted the attention of Sauron's agents, who ransacked the hobbits' rooms in the night. The group, under Aragorn's guidance, quickly fled through the\u00a0Midgewater Marshes\u00a0and again escaped the Nazg\u00fbl.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

While encamped at\u00a0Amon S\u00fbl, they were found and attacked by five Nazg\u00fbl. The chief of the Nazg\u00fbl, known as the\u00a0Witch-king of Angmar, stabbed Frodo with a\u00a0Morgul-blade, before Aragorn routed all five of them with fire. A piece of this blade remained in Frodo's shoulder and, working its way towards his heart, threatened to turn him into a wraith under the control of the Witch-king. With the help of his companions and\u00a0Glorfindel, Frodo was able to evade the remaining Ringwraiths and reach Rivendell. Although almost overcome by his wound, once there he was healed over time by Elrond; it was said and later seen that the wound would never completely heal, however, as it was as much spiritual as physical.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

In Rivendell, the\u00a0Council of Elrond\u00a0met and resolved to destroy the Ring by casting it into\u00a0Mount Doom\u00a0in\u00a0Mordor, the realm of Sauron. Frodo, realizing that he was destined for this task, stepped forward to be the\u00a0Ring-bearer. A\u00a0Fellowship of nine companions\u00a0was formed to guide and protect him: the hobbits, Gandalf, Aragorn, the\u00a0dwarf\u00a0Gimli, the\u00a0elf\u00a0Legolas\u00a0of\u00a0Mirkwood, and\u00a0Boromir, a man of\u00a0Gondor. Together they set out from Rivendell. Frodo was armed with\u00a0Sting, Bilbo's Elvish knife, and wore Bilbo's coat of Dwarven mail made of\u00a0mithril. The company, seeking a way over the\u00a0Misty Mountains, first tried the Pass of\u00a0Caradhras, but abandoned it in favour of the\u00a0mines of Moria. In Moria Frodo was stabbed by an\u00a0Orc-spear, but his coat of\u00a0mithril\u00a0armour saved his life. They were led through the mines by Gandalf, until he fell battling a\u00a0Balrog, and then by Aragorn to\u00a0Lothl\u00f3rien. There\u00a0Galadriel, the Lady of the Woods, gave Frodo an\u00a0Elven cloak\u00a0and a\u00a0phial\u00a0carrying the Light of\u00a0E\u00e4rendil\u00a0to aid him on his dangerous quest.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

Having then travelled some miles down the\u00a0Anduin\u00a0by boat, the Fellowship reached\u00a0Parth Galen. There, Boromir, having fallen to the lure of the Ring, tried to take it by force from Frodo. Frodo escaped by putting on the Ring and becoming invisible. This event broke the Fellowship; Boromir was later slain defending Merry and Pippin from invading Orcs, who captured the two hobbits. Aragorn, Gimli and Legolas gave him a hero's funeral before setting out after the two hobbits. Frodo chose to continue the quest alone, but Sam followed his master, joining him on the journey to Mordor.

", "type": "paragraph"}]

[{"value": "

Samwise\u00a0\"Sam\"\u00a0Gamgee\u00a0/\u02c8s\u00e6m\u02ccwa\u026az\u00a0\u02c8\u0261\u00e6m\u02ccd\u0292i\u02d0/\u00a0(later known as Samwise Gardner)[1]\u00a0is a\u00a0fictional character\u00a0in\u00a0J. R. R. Tolkien's legendarium. Samwise is one of the main characters of\u00a0The Lord of the Rings, in which he fills an\u00a0archetypical\u00a0role as the\u00a0sidekick\u00a0of the primary\u00a0protagonist,\u00a0Frodo Baggins. Sam is a member of the\u00a0Fellowship of the Ring.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"header_text": "Literature", "size": "h2"}, "type": "header"}, {"value": "

Samwise Gamgee is first introduced in\u00a0The Fellowship of the Ring. Sam is\u00a0Frodo Baggins' gardener, having inherited the position as Baggins' gardener from his father,\u00a0Hamfast \"Gaffer\" Gamgee. At the time of the War of the Ring, Sam was living in Number 3,\u00a0Bagshot Row\u00a0with his father.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

As \"punishment\" for\u00a0eavesdropping\u00a0on\u00a0Gandalf's conversation with Frodo regarding the\u00a0One Ring, Sam was made Frodo's first companion on his journey to\u00a0Rivendell. They were joined by\u00a0Meriadoc Brandybuck\u00a0and\u00a0Peregrin Took, Frodo's cousins, and journeyed together to\u00a0Rivendell, where the\u00a0Council of Elrond\u00a0took place and Sam joined the Fellowship of the Ring.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"attribute_name": "Samwise Gamgee", "attribute_group": "Return of the King", "text": "'Come, Mr. Frodo!' he cried. 'I can't carry it for you, but I can carry you.'"}, "type": "blockquote"}, {"value": "

When the Fellowship was split up at the\u00a0Falls of Rauros, Sam insisted on accompanying Frodo. Sam protected and cared for Frodo, who was growing weaker under the Ring's influence, as they moved through the dangerous lands toward\u00a0Mordor. Sam distrusted\u00a0Gollum, who became their guide into Mordor. His suspicions were proven right when Gollum betrayed them to the giant spider\u00a0Shelob. After Shelob apparently killed Frodo, Sam drove her off. When a band of\u00a0orcs\u00a0approached, Sam was forced to leave the apparently dead Frodo and take the Ring himself, and briefly became a\u00a0Ring-bearer. He was momentarily tempted by its promise of power, but did not succumb to it, subsequently rescuing Frodo (who had only been paralysed) from the Orcs who held him captive. Sam also returned the Ring to Frodo, making him the only Ring-bearer to freely give up the Ring without intervention. The two then journeyed alone through Mordor and into the heart of\u00a0Mount Doom, where Gollum attacked Frodo and reclaimed the Ring, only to inadvertently destroy both it and himself by falling into the mountain's lava.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "https://youtu.be/l1eLHoDxMNE", "type": "embed"}, {"value": "

After the hobbits' return home and the\u00a0Battle of Bywater, Sam travelled the length and breadth of\u00a0the Shire\u00a0replanting trees that had been cut down during\u00a0Saruman's brief reign. He used the gift of earth given to him by the Lady\u00a0Galadriel, which caused the saplings he planted to grow at an accelerated rate. The small amount remaining he took to the\u00a0Three-Farthing Stone\u00a0(roughly the centre of the Shire) and cast into the air, prompting the bountiful period of growth starting in the spring of the year 1420 (Shire Reckoning). The greatest wonder was a young\u00a0mallorn\u00a0tree sprouting in the Party Field: \"the only\u00a0mallorn\u00a0west of the Mountains and east of the Sea\" (grown from a nut included as part of Galadriel's gift).

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

After the War of the Ring, Sam married\u00a0Rose \"Rosie\" Cotton\u00a0and moved to\u00a0Bag End\u00a0with Frodo. Sam and Rosie had 13 children:\u00a0Elanor the Fair, Frodo, Rose, Merry, Pippin, Goldilocks, Hamfast, Daisy, Primrose, Bilbo, Ruby, Robin, and Tolman (Tom). Sam was elected\u00a0Mayor of the Shire\u00a0for seven consecutive seven-year terms and came to be known as Samwise Gardner.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

After Sam and Rose's first child was born, Frodo told Sam he would leave\u00a0Middle-earth, along with\u00a0Bilbo Baggins, Gandalf and most of the remaining High\u00a0Elves, for the\u00a0Undying Lands. Before Frodo left, he gave the estate of Bag End to Sam, as well as the\u00a0Red Book of Westmarch\u00a0for Sam to continue, hinting that Sam might also be allowed to travel into the West eventually.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

After the death of his wife in the year 62 of the\u00a0Fourth Age\u00a0(Shire Reckoning\u00a01482), Sam entrusted the Red Book to Elanor and left the Shire at the age of 102. He was not seen again in Middle-earth, but Elanor and her descendants preserved the tradition that he went to the\u00a0Grey Havens\u00a0and sailed into the West. As the last of the Ring-bearers, he was entitled to sail across the Sea and be reunited with Frodo in the Undying Lands.

", "type": "paragraph"}]

[{"value": "

Gandalf\u00a0/\u02c8\u0261\u00e6nd\u0251\u02d0lf/[2]\u00a0is a\u00a0fictional character\u00a0and one of the protagonists in\u00a0J. R. R. Tolkien's novels\u00a0The Hobbit\u00a0and\u00a0The Lord of the Rings. He is a\u00a0wizard, member of the\u00a0Istari\u00a0order, as well as leader of the\u00a0Fellowship of the Ring\u00a0and the army of the West. In\u00a0The Lord of the Rings, he is initially known as\u00a0Gandalf the Grey, but returns from death as\u00a0Gandalf the White.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"header_text": "The Fellowship of the Ring", "size": "h2"}, "type": "header"}, {"value": "

Returning to\u00a0the Shire, in\u00a0T.A.\u00a03018, Gandalf confirmed his suspicions by throwing\u00a0the Ring\u00a0into\u00a0Frodo's hearth-fire and reading the writing that appeared on\u00a0the Ring's surface. He told Frodo the full history of the Ring, and urged him to take the Ring to\u00a0Rivendell; for he would be in grave danger if he stayed in the Shire. Gandalf said he would attempt to return for Frodo's 50th birthday party, in order to accompany him on the road thereafter; and that meanwhile Frodo should arrange to leave quietly, as the servants of\u00a0Sauron\u00a0would be searching for him.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

Outside the Shire, Gandalf encountered\u00a0Radagast the Brown, another of the Istari, who brought the news that the\u00a0Nazg\u00fbl\u00a0had ridden forth and crossed the River\u00a0Anduin\u2014and a request from\u00a0Saruman\u00a0that Gandalf come to\u00a0Isengard. Gandalf left a\u00a0letter\u00a0to Frodo (urging his immediate departure) with\u00a0Barliman Butterbur\u00a0at the inn in\u00a0Bree, and headed towards Isengard. There Saruman revealed his true colours, urging Gandalf to help him obtain the Ring for his own use. Gandalf refused, and Saruman imprisoned him at the top of the tower of\u00a0Orthanc. Eventually Gandalf was rescued by\u00a0Gwaihir\u00a0the\u00a0Eagle.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

Gwaihir set Gandalf down in\u00a0Rohan, where Gandalf appealed to King\u00a0Th\u00e9oden\u00a0for a horse. Th\u00e9oden, under the malign influence of\u00a0Gr\u00edma Wormtongue, Saruman's spy, told Gandalf to take any horse he pleased, but to leave quickly. It was then that Gandalf met the great horse\u00a0Shadowfax, one of the\u00a0mearas, who would be his mount and companion for most of the rest of the war. Gandalf pursued the horse for two days[6]\u00a0before Shadowfax permitted Gandalf to ride him. Gandalf then rode hard for the Shire, but did not reach it until Frodo had already set out. Knowing that Frodo and his companions would be heading for Rivendell, Gandalf began to make his own way there. He learned at Bree that the Hobbits had fallen in with\u00a0Aragorn. He faced the Nazg\u00fbl at\u00a0Weathertop\u00a0but escaped after an all-night battle, drawing four of them northward. Frodo, Aragorn and company faced the remaining five on Weathertop a few nights later. Gandalf reached Rivendell just before Frodo's arrival.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

In Rivendell, Gandalf helped\u00a0Elrond\u00a0drive off the Nazg\u00fbl pursuing Frodo and played a great part in the following\u00a0council\u00a0as the only person who knew the full history of the Ring. He also revealed that Saruman had betrayed them and was in league with Sauron. When it was decided that the Ring had to be destroyed, Gandalf volunteered to accompany Frodo\u2014now the Ring-bearer\u2014in his quest. He also persuaded Elrond to let Frodo's cousins\u00a0Merry\u00a0and\u00a0Pippin\u00a0join the\u00a0Fellowship.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

Taking charge of the Fellowship (comprising nine representatives of the free peoples of\u00a0Middle-earth, \"set against the Nine Riders\"), Gandalf and Aragorn led the Hobbits and their companions south. After an unsuccessful attempt to cross Mount\u00a0Caradhras\u00a0in winter, they crossed\u00a0under\u00a0the mountains through the Mines of\u00a0Moria, though only\u00a0Gimli\u00a0the\u00a0Dwarf\u00a0was enthusiastic about that route. In Moria, they discovered that the Dwarf colony established there earlier had been overrun by\u00a0Orcs. The Fellowship fought with the Orcs and Trolls of Moria and escaped them.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

At the\u00a0Bridge of Khazad-d\u00fbm, they encountered \"Durin's Bane,\" a fearsome\u00a0Balrog\u00a0from ancient times. Gandalf faced the Balrog to enable the others to escape. After a brief exchange of blows, Gandalf broke the bridge beneath the Balrog with his\u00a0staff. As the Balrog fell, it wrapped its whip around Gandalf's legs, dragging him over the edge. As his friends looked on in horror, Gandalf fell into the abyss, crying \"Fly, you fools!\" as he went.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

After a long fall, Gandalf and the Balrog crashed into a deep subterranean lake far under Moria. Gandalf pursued the Balrog through the tunnels for eight days until they climbed to the peak of\u00a0Zirakzigil. Here they fought for two days and nights. In the end, the Balrog was defeated and cast down onto the mountainside. Gandalf himself died shortly afterwards, and his body lay on the peak while his spirit travelled \"out of thought and time\".

", "type": "paragraph"}]

[{"value": "

Bilbo Baggins\u00a0is the\u00a0title character\u00a0and\u00a0protagonist\u00a0of\u00a0J. R. R. Tolkien's 1937 novel\u00a0The Hobbit, as well as a\u00a0supporting character\u00a0in\u00a0The Lord of the Rings. In Tolkien's narrative\u00a0conceit, in which all the writings of\u00a0Middle-earth\u00a0are translations from the fictitious volume of\u00a0The\u00a0Red Book of Westmarch, Bilbo is the author of\u00a0The Hobbit\u00a0and translator of various \"works from the\u00a0elvish\" (as mentioned in the end of\u00a0The Return of the King).

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"header_text": "The Hobbit", "size": "h2"}, "type": "header"}, {"value": {"caption": "Bilbo Baggins illustration", "image": 28, "style": "half"}, "type": "image"}, {"value": "

In\u00a0The Hobbit, Bilbo Baggins, a\u00a0hobbit\u00a0in comfortable middle age at 50 years old, was hired despite his objections as a \"burglar\" by the\u00a0wizard\u00a0Gandalf\u00a0and\u00a013 Dwarves\u00a0led by their king\u00a0Thorin Oakenshield\u00a0on a quest to reclaim the\u00a0Lonely Mountain\u00a0and its treasure from the\u00a0dragon\u00a0Smaug. The adventure took Bilbo and the companions through the wilderness, to the\u00a0elf\u00a0haven of\u00a0Rivendell, across the\u00a0Misty Mountains\u00a0and the black forest of\u00a0Mirkwood, to\u00a0Lake-town\u00a0in the middle of\u00a0Long Lake, and eventually to the Mountain itself. Here, after the dragon was killed and the Mountain was reclaimed, soon after that the\u00a0Battle of Five Armies\u00a0took place.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

In his journey, Bilbo encountered other fantastic creatures, including\u00a0trolls, elves,\u00a0giant spiders, a\u00a0man who can change shape into a bear,\u00a0goblins,\u00a0eagles,\u00a0wolves\u00a0and a slimy, murderous creature named\u00a0Gollum. Underground, near Gollum's lair, Bilbo accidentally found a\u00a0magic ring of invisibility, which he used to escape from Gollum.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

By the end of the journey, Bilbo had become wiser and more confident, having saved the day in many precarious situations. Bilbo's journey has been compared to a pilgrimage of grace. The Hobbit can be characterized as a \"Christian\u00a0bildungsroman\u00a0which equates progress to wisdom gained in the form of a rite of passage.[1]\u00a0He rescued the dwarves from giant spiders with the magic ring and a short\u00a0Elven-sword\u00a0he acquired. He used the ring to sneak around in dangerous places, as well as his wits to smuggle the dwarves out of the elves' prisons. When tensions arose over ownership of the recovered treasure, he tried unsuccessfully to bring the opposing sides to compromise, using the\u00a0Arkenstone, a stolen heirloom jewel, as leverage. This strained his relationship with Thorin, but the two were reconciled at Thorin's deathbed. At the end of the story, Bilbo returned to his home in\u00a0the Shire\u00a0only to find that several of his relatives, believing him to be dead, were trying to claim his home and possessions. In addition to becoming wealthy from his share of the dwarves' treasure, he found that he, like\u00a0Adam, had traded respectability for experience and wisdom. At the end, Gandalf proclaims Bilbo is no longer the Hobbit he was. This is certainly true as Bilbo has fully matured. Continuing the pilgrimage theme, a true pilgrimage does not end at the destination, but rather when the wanderer is absolved, blessed, and ready to return home.[1]

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"header_text": "The Lord of the Rings", "size": "h2"}, "type": "header"}, {"value": "

The Fellowship of the Ring, the first volume of\u00a0The Lord of the Rings, begins with Bilbo's \"eleventy-first\" (111th) birthday, 60 years after the beginning of\u00a0The Hobbit. The main character of the novel is\u00a0Frodo Baggins, Bilbo's cousin,[nb 1]\u00a0who celebrates his 33rd birthday and legally comes of age on the same day.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

In\u00a0T.A.\u00a02989 (S.R.\u00a01389), Bilbo, a lifelong bachelor, adopted Frodo, the orphaned son of his first cousin\u00a0Primula Brandybuck\u00a0and his second cousin\u00a0Drogo Baggins, and made him his heir. Though Frodo was actually \"his first\u00a0and\u00a0second\u00a0cousin once removed\u00a0either way\",[2]\u00a0the two regarded each other as uncle and nephew.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

All this time Bilbo had kept his magic ring, with no idea of its significance, using it mostly to hide from his obnoxious cousins, the\u00a0Sackville-Bagginses, when they came to visit.\u00a0Gandalf's investigations revealed it to be the\u00a0One Ring\u00a0forged by the Dark Lord\u00a0Sauron. The Ring had prolonged Bilbo's life beyond the normal hobbit span, and at 111 he still looked 50. While the Ring did not initially corrupt him as it had its previous owners, it was beginning to affect him; over the years, it had begun to prey on his mind when out of his sight, and he lost sleep and felt \"thin, sort of\u00a0stretched\u00a0\u2026 like butter that has been scraped over too much bread\".[2]

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

On the night of his and Frodo's birthday, Bilbo threw himself a party and invited all of the Shire. He signed his home,\u00a0Bag End, and estate over to Frodo. He then gave a farewell address to his neighbors, at the end of which he put on the Ring and vanished from sight. As Bilbo prepared finally to leave the house, he reacted with panic and suspicion when Gandalf tried to persuade him to leave the Ring with Frodo. Bilbo refused to give up the Ring, referring to it as his \"precious\" \u2013 just as Gollum had. Gandalf lost his temper with his old friend and talked some sense into him. Bilbo admitted he would have liked to be rid of the Ring, and he left it behind, becoming the first person to do so voluntarily. He left the Shire that night, and was never seen in\u00a0Hobbiton\u00a0again.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

His earlier adventure, his\u00a0eccentric\u00a0habits as a hobbit, and his sudden disappearance led to the enduring figure of \"Mad Baggins\" in hobbit folklore, who disappeared with a flash and a bang and returned with gold and jewels.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

Freed of the Ring's power over his senses, Bilbo travelled first to\u00a0Rivendell, and then on to visit the dwarves of the Lonely Mountain. After he returned to Rivendell he spent much of the next 17 years living a pleasant life of retirement: eating, sleeping, writing poetry, and working on his memoirs,\u00a0There and Back Again, known as\u00a0The Hobbit. He became a scholar of Elven lore, leaving behind the\u00a0Translations from the\u00a0Elvish, which forms the basis of what is known to us as\u00a0The Silmarillion.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

When Frodo and his friends\u00a0Samwise Gamgee,\u00a0Meriadoc Brandybuck\u00a0and\u00a0Peregrin Took\u00a0stopped in Rivendell on their quest to destroy the Ring, Bilbo was still alive but now visibly aged, the years having caught up with him after he surrendered the Ring. Upon seeing the Ring again, he suddenly tried to take it from Frodo; he returned to his senses when a terrified Frodo backed away, and he broke down in tears, apologizing for bringing the burden of the Ring onto Frodo.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

After the quest to destroy the Ring was fulfilled in\u00a0The Return of the King, Gandalf and the four Hobbits visited Rivendell on their way back to the Shire and found Bilbo still living there. He gave Frodo a set of manuscripts that later became\u00a0Translations from the Elvish, and also gave Sam a small bag of gold that represented the last of his share from Smaug's vast hoard. Two years later Bilbo accompanied Gandalf,\u00a0Elrond,\u00a0Galadriel, and Frodo to the\u00a0Grey Havens, there to take ship for\u00a0Tol Eress\u00eba\u00a0across the sea, on 29th 'September'\u00a0T.A.\u00a03021. He had already celebrated his 131st birthday by this time, surpassing the\u00a0Old Took\u00a0by one year and becoming the oldest Hobbit ever in Middle-earth. (The natural lifespan of Hobbits is about 100 years.)[3]

", "type": "paragraph"}]

fields.introduction: Elen sila lumenn omentilmo, Nae saian luume'. Cormamin lindua ele lle. Saesa omentien lle, vanya sulie Namaarie. Aa' lasser en lle coia orn n' omenta gurtha.

fields.body:
[{"value": "

In\u00a0J. R. R. Tolkien's\u00a0fictional world\u00a0of\u00a0Middle-earth,\u00a0Mordor\u00a0(pronounced\u00a0[\u02c8m\u0254rd\u0254r]; from\u00a0Sindarin\u00a0Black Land\u00a0and\u00a0Quenya\u00a0Land of Shadow) was the region occupied and controlled by\u00a0Sauron, in the southeast of northwestern Middle-earth to the East of\u00a0Anduin, the great river.\u00a0Orodruin, a volcano in Mordor, was the goal of the\u00a0Fellowship of the Ring\u00a0(and later\u00a0Frodo Baggins\u00a0and\u00a0Sam Gamgee) in the quest to destroy the\u00a0One Ring.

Mordor has three enormous mountain ranges surrounding it, from the north, from the west and from the south. The mountains both protected the land from an unexpected invasion by any of the people living in those directions and kept those living in Mordor from escaping. Tolkien was reported to have identified Mordor with the volcano of\u00a0Stromboli\u00a0off Sicily, in terms of geographic equivalency with the real world.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"caption": "Barad-d\u00fbr looking over Mount Doom", "image": 16, "style": "contain"}, "type": "image"}, {"value": {"header_text": "Geography", "size": "h2"}, "type": "header"}, {"value": "

Three sides of Mordor were bounded by mountain ranges, arranged in a rough rectangle: the Ered Lithui (translated as 'Ash Mountains') on the north, and the Ephel D\u00faath (literally, \"Fence of Shadow\") on the west and the south. In the northwest the pass of Cirith Gorgor led into the enclosed plain of Ud\u00fbn. Sauron built the Black Gate of Mordor (the Morannon) across the pass, joining the Towers of the Teeth, two earlier guard towers built by Gondor to keep a watch on this entrance. The passage through the inner side of Ud\u00fbn into the interior of Mordor was guarded by another gate, the Isenmouthe. Outside the Morannon lay the Dagorlad or Battle Plain.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

In the interior within this mountainous border lay Sauron's main fortress Barad-d\u00fbr, the arid plateau of Gorgoroth, and Mount Doom. To the east lay the plain of Lithlad. A narrow pass led through the Ephel D\u00faath, guarded by Minas Morgul (earlier Minas Ithil). A higher, more difficult pass, Cirith Ungol, just to the north, was guarded by a tower originally built by Gondor. This pass, \"the pass of the spider\", was also blockaded by Torech Ungol, the lair of the giant spider Shelob. The fortress Durthang lay in the northern Ephel D\u00faath above Ud\u00fbn.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "https://youtu.be/jk9wwlzuwJE", "type": "embed"}, {"value": "

N\u00farn, the southern part of Mordor, was less arid and more fertile. Streams here fed the salt Sea of N\u00farnen. Sauron's slaves farmed this region to support his armies.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

Inside the Ephel D\u00faath ran a lower parallel ridge, the Morgai, separated from the Ephel D\u00faath by a narrow valley that Frodo and Sam followed northward after escaping from Cirith Ungol. Water trickled into this vale from the Ephel D\u00faath, and the text describes it as a \"dying land not yet dead\". The vegetation included \"low scrubby trees\", \"coarse grey grass-tussocks\", \"withered mosses\", \"great writhing, tangled brambles\", and thickets of briars with long, stabbing thorns. The fauna included maggots, midges, and flies marked with \"a red eye-shaped blotch\".

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

Adjacent to Mordor were, to the west, the narrow land of Ithilien (a province of Gondor); to the northwest the Dead Marshes; to the northeast Rh\u00fbn; to the southeast Khand; and to the south Harad.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

In The Atlas of Middle-earth, Karen Wynn Fonstad assumed that the lands of Mordor, Khand, and Rh\u00fbn lay where the inland Sea of Helcar had been, and that the Sea of Rh\u00fbn and Sea of N\u00farnen were its remnants. This assumption stemmed from a First Age world-map drawn by Tolkien in the Ambarkanta, where the Inland Sea of Helcar occupied a large area of Middle-earth between the Ered Luin and Orocarni, with the western end being close to the head of the Great Gulf (later the Mouths of Anduin).[2] The atlas was however published before The Peoples of Middle-earth, in which the Sea of Rh\u00fbn and Mordor exist already in the First Age.

", "type": "paragraph"}]

[{"value": "

Minas Tirith\u00a0(/\u02c8m\u026an\u0259s\u00a0\u02c8t\u026ar\u026a\u03b8/;\u00a0Sindarin:\u00a0/\u02c8minas \u02c8tiri\u03b8/), originally named\u00a0Minas Anor, is a fictional city and castle in\u00a0J. R. R. Tolkien's\u00a0Middle-earth\u00a0writings. It became the heavily fortified\u00a0capital\u00a0of\u00a0Gondor\u00a0in the second half of the\u00a0Third Age. It was originally built to guard the former capital,\u00a0Osgiliath, from attack from the west, but became the capital when Osgiliath fell into ruin following the\u00a0Kin-strife\u00a0and the\u00a0Great Plague. It is often referred to as the\u00a0White City\u00a0(though that name is not in the book) and the\u00a0City of the Kings. The\u00a0Rohirrimsometimes translated this into\u00a0their own language\u00a0as \"the\u00a0Mundburg\". In the climax of\u00a0The Lord of the Rings\u00a0the city comes under a very large and determined attack by the allied forces of\u00a0Mordor.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"header_text": "Description", "size": "h2"}, "type": "header"}, {"value": "

The name\u00a0Minas Tirith\u00a0means \"The Tower of Guard\" or \"The Tower of Watch\" in the\u00a0Elvish\u00a0language\u00a0Sindarin.[1]\u00a0It was originally named\u00a0Minas Anor, \"The Tower of the Setting Sun\", in connection with\u00a0Minas Ithil, \"The Tower of the Rising Moon\". Minas Ithil was later conquered by\u00a0orcs\u00a0from\u00a0Mordor\u00a0and was renamed\u00a0Minas Morgul, \"The Tower of Black Sorcery\".

The city of Minas Tirith covered an entire hill, the Hill of Guard, and was built on seven levels, culminating in the Citadel at the summit. Each level was about 100\u00a0ft (30\u00a0m) higher than the one below it, and each surrounded by a white wall, with the exception of the wall of the First Circle (the lowest level), which was black. The outer face of this outer wall, the lowest, was made of black stone, the same material used in\u00a0Orthanc; it was vulnerable only to earthquakes capable of rending the ground where it stood.[2]

Each wall held a gate, and each gate faced a different direction from the one in the next lower wall. The city's main street snaked up the hill and through each of the gates.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"caption": "White Tree of Gondor in Minas Tirith", "image": 17, "style": "full"}, "type": "image"}, {"value": {"header_text": "Great Gate", "size": "h2"}, "type": "header"}, {"value": "

The Great Gate was the main gate on the first level of the City of Minas Tirith. It was in the City Wall \u2014 or Othram \u2014 facing eastward across the Pelennor Fields toward the\u00a0Anduin.

In front of the Great Gate there was a large paved area called the Gateway. The main roads to Minas Tirith met here: the\u00a0North-way\u00a0that became the\u00a0Great West Road\u00a0to\u00a0Rohan; the\u00a0South Road\u00a0to the southern provinces of Gondor; and the\u00a0road to Osgiliath.

The Great Gate was very strong, constructed of iron and steel and guarded by stone towers and bastions. The iron doors of the Gate rolled back to open. Passwords were required to enter the Great Gate and each of the six other gates of Minas Tirith. The Great Gate was breached during the\u00a0War of the Ring.\u00a0Sauron's forces under the command of the\u00a0Witch-king of Angmar\u00a0besieged the City on 13th 'March'. Before dawn on 15th 'March', the battering ram\u00a0Grond\u00a0smashed into the Great Gate three times while the Witch-king spoke words of power. \"As if stricken by some blasting spell it burst asunder: there was a flash of searing lightning, and the doors tumbled in riven fragments to the ground.\"[3]\u00a0The Witch-king rode through the Gate where\u00a0Gandalf\u00a0awaited him, but then the Rohirrim arrived and the Witch-king went to fight them in the\u00a0Battle of the Pelennor Fields\u00a0where he was slain.

A temporary barricade was erected in place of the Great Gate. After the War, on 1st 'May',\u00a0Aragorn\u00a0received the\u00a0Crown of Gondor\u00a0in front of the gate and then entered the City.

The Great Gate was rebuilt of\u00a0mithril\u00a0(the hardest of all metals in Tolkien's writing) and steel by\u00a0Gimli\u00a0and Dwarves of\u00a0Erebor\u00a0from the\u00a0Lonely Mountain\u00a0who had settled in the\u00a0Glittering Caves.

", "type": "paragraph"}]

[{"value": {"caption": "A shield displaying the White Hand of Isengard", "image": 7, "style": "half"}, "type": "image"}, {"value": "

In J. R. R. Tolkien's fictional universe of Middle-earth, Isengard ([\u02c8a\u026a\u02d0.z\u025bn.\u0261\u0251rd]), a translation of the Sindarin Angrenost, was a large fortress. Both names mean \"Iron fortress\" (cf. German Eisen and Old English is\u00e6rn = iron),[1] though Isengard has a second meaning of \"West Guard\".

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"header_text": "Armour and emblems", "size": "h2"}, "type": "header"}, {"value": "

The Orcs of Isengard bore upon their shields a White Hand on a black field, and on their helmets an S-rune (<) to signify Saruman. A carved and painted White Hand of stone was set on a black pillar outside the gates of Isengard.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"header_text": "Orthanc", "size": "h2"}, "type": "header"}, {"value": "

Orthanc is the black tower of Isengard. Its name means both \"Mount Fang\" in Sindarin, and \"Cunning Mind\" in Old English, the language Tolkien uses to \"translate\" Rohirric.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

Orthanc was, according to J. R. R. Tolkien's legendarium, built during the end of the Second Age by men of Gondor out of four many-sided columns of rock joined together by an unknown process and then hardened. No known weapon could harm it. Although the Ents could split ordinary stone with ease, their assault on the tower only left a few scratches and chips on its surface. Orthanc rose up to more than 500 feet (150 meters) above the plain of Isengard, and ended in four sharp peaks. Its only entrance was at the top of a high stair, and above that was a small window and balcony.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

Orthanc housed one of the palant\u00edri of the South Kingdom, and was guarded by a special warden. In the days of the early Stewards the tower was locked and its keys taken to Minas Tirith. When Isengard fell to the Dunlendings in T.A. 2710 they were unable to enter the tower.

", "type": "paragraph"}]

[{"value": "

In\u00a0J. R. R. Tolkien's\u00a0Middle-earth\u00a0high fantasy\u00a0writings,\u00a0Helm's Deep\u00a0was a large valley in the north-western\u00a0Ered Nimrais\u00a0(White Mountains).

The valley was described as being blocked over its entire width by the natural series of hills called\u00a0Helm's Dike\u00a0and behind that lay the fortress of Aglarond or the\u00a0Hornburg, at the entrance to the Glittering Caves.

In the Appendices of\u00a0The Lord of the Rings, the history of the valley states that it was home to a small\u00a0Gondorian\u00a0regiment, but after the place which was called\u00a0Calenardhon\u00a0became\u00a0Rohan, it became an encampment of the\u00a0Rohirrim, where the guards of the\u00a0Fords of Isen\u00a0lived.

It also states that during the war with the\u00a0Dunlendings\u00a0under\u00a0Wulf, the Rohirrim under King\u00a0Helm Hammerhand\u00a0and many of his people sought refuge in the\u00a0keep, where they held out during the winter of\u00a0T.A.\u00a02758\u20132759.

The castle itself was described as having a long causeway which wound up to the great gate of the fortress itself. Inside the keep there were stables and an armoury, as well as a great hall in the rear which was dug out of the mountainside. There also was a great tower (the Hornburg) the top of which consisted of the great horn of\u00a0Helm Hammerhand. The Deep, which was described as standing next to the fortress, was barred by the long Deeping Wall, which was described as consisting of solid rock except for a small culvert which allowed water from the Deeping Stream to enter; this rendered a fresh supply in sieges of great length. The Deeping Wall itself is described as standing 20 feet tall; and also being wide enough for four men to stand side by side. Access to the fortress from within the Deep was made possible by a long stair which led to the Hornburg's rear gate.

In\u00a0The Two Towers, the fortress guarding Helm's Deep becomes the refuge of the main army of the Rohirrim, under King\u00a0Th\u00e9oden\u00a0during the\u00a0War of the Ring. Th\u00e9oden said that \"the Hornburg has never fallen to assault\" giving an impression of invulnerability. This was tested during the\u00a0Battle of the Hornburg, as a massive army of\u00a0Uruk-hai\u00a0sent by\u00a0Saruman\u00a0almost overwhelmed the defences of the Rohirrim. Saruman's\u00a0orcs\u00a0used an explosive blast of fire within the culvert which, when detonated, breached the long Deeping Wall. The origin of this explosion is unclear and Tolkien denotes it as \"Saruman's devilry\". The Rohirrim defenders held out long enough in the fortress until dawn, giving Gandalf time to gather and lead a counter-attack, while Th\u00e9oden led a cavalry charge that drove the Orcs from the fortress.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"caption": "Crest of Gondor, the original builders of the Helm", "image": 9, "style": "half"}, "type": "image"}, {"value": {"header_text": "Aglarond", "size": "h2"}, "type": "header"}, {"value": "

Aglarond and Angrenost (which later became Isengard) were the two fortresses built by Gondor to guard the approaches to the Fords of Isen. Like Angrenost to the north, it was initially well guarded, but as the population of Calenardhon (the later Rohan) dwindled it was not maintained and, losing importance, was left to a hereditary small guard who intermarried with Dunlendings.


When Cirion, Steward of Gondor, gave Calenardhon to the \u00c9oth\u00e9od, Aglarond was transferred into the care of the Rohirrim, who named it S\u00fathburg (southern burg in their language). The Gondorian guard was merged with that of Angrenost to the north, which remained in the keep of Gondor. Guard duty of the Fords was initially shared between Gondor and Rohan, but later maintained only by the Rohirrim.


During the reign of Helm Hammerhand, Rohan was attacked by Dunlendings from across the river Isen. Edoras was taken, and Helm and many of his people retreated to S\u00fathburg. Because Helm always blew a great horn before riding out to fight the beleaguering Dunlendings, the keep was renamed Hornburg. During the War of the Ring, the Hornburg was the refuge of the Rohirrim as they defended Helm's Deep.


After the war, Gimli the Dwarf, who fought in that battle, established a colony of Durin's folk there. Aglarond lay in front of a huge and very beautiful cave system, which proved irresistible to him. Gimli became known as 'the Lord of the Glittering Caves', although this new realm was presumably under the overlordship of Thorin Stonehelm, his kinsman and heir of the lordship of all Durin's Folk. The dwarves of Aglarond restored the Hornburg following the War of the Ring, and it became a fortress they shared with the Rohirrim.

", "type": "paragraph"}]

[{"value": {"caption": "The Uffington White Horse, whence the banner and shield of the House of Eorl – a "white horse upon green" – is derived.", "image": 11, "style": "half"}, "type": "image"}, {"value": "

The capital of Rohan is the hill fort of Edoras which is located on a hill in a valley of the White Mountains. Meduseld, the Golden Hall of the King of Rohan, is located there. "Edoras" is Old English for "enclosures",[4] which Tolkien held to be a translation of an unknown Rohirric name of the same meaning. The city of Edoras was built by Rohan's second King, Brego son of Eorl the Young. Before Edoras was completed, Rohan's capital was at Aldburg in the Folde. Meduseld is described as having a golden thatch. Edoras is built at the end of the valley of Harrowdale, which lies under the great mountain Starkhorn. The river Snowbourn flows past the city on its way east towards the Entwash. The city is protected only by a high wall of timber, and a one-way road allows access to the city. Just before the gates, two rows of mounds line the road, which are the graves of the former Kings of Rohan. "Meduseld", a modernised form of the Old English Maeduselde,[5] is similarly meant to be a translation of an unknown Rohirric name meaning "mead hall". Meduseld is a large hall with roof that appears golden from far off. The walls are richly decorated with tapestries depicting the history and legends of the Rohirrim, and it serves as a house for the King and his kin, a meeting hall for the King and his advisors, and a gathering hall.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

Edoras is Rohan's only real city. It is at Meduseld that Aragorn, Gimli, Legolas, and Gandalf meet with King Théoden in the account of the early stages of the War of the Ring.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

Another settlement is Aldburg, capital of the Eastfold and original settlement of Eorl the Young. A third settlement is Snowbourne, named after the river of the same name which runs nearby. It is similar in appearance to the hill-fort of Edoras. Dunharrow is a refuge in the White Mountains. Helm's Deep is a valley in the White Mountains in which the Hornburg, a major fortress of Rohan, is located.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"header_text": "Internal history", "size": "h2"}, "type": "header"}, {"value": "

In the thirteenth century of the Third Age (T.A.), the Kings of Gondor made close alliances with the Northmen of Rhovanion, a people said in The Lord of the Rings to be akin to the Three Houses of Men (later the Dúnedain) from the First Age.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

In the twenty-first century, a remnant tribe of such Northmen calling itself the Éothéod moved from the valleys of Anduin to the north west of Mirkwood, clearing out what remained of the recently defeated witch kingdom of Angmar, east of the Misty Mountains. While there, some dispute arose between them and the Dwarves over the treasure-hoard of Scatha the dragon.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

Later, in 2509, Cirion the Steward of Gondor sent summons to the Éothéod for aid in throwing off a combined invasion of Men from the north east of Middle-earth, and Orcs from Mordor.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

Eorl the Young, king of the Éothéod, answered the summons, and arrived unexpected at a decisive battle at the Field of Celebrant, routing the orc army, and then destroying it as it fled.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

As a reward, Eorl was given the plains of Calenardhon, and he moved his kingdom there. This land had earlier been part of Gondor proper, but had been devastated by the plague of 1636, and the survivors to a large extent slain in the invasion mentioned above.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"attribute_name": "Aragorn", "attribute_group": "Reciting a forgotten poem on Eorl the Young", "text": "Where now the horse and the rider? Where is the horn that was blowing? Where is the helm and the hauberk, and the bright hair flowing? Where is the hand on the harp-string, and the red fire glowing? Where is the spring and the harvest and the tall corn growing?"}, "type": "blockquote"}, {"value": "

The first line of kings lasted for 249 years, until the ninth king Helm Hammerhand died. His sons had been killed earlier, and his nephew Fréaláf Hildeson began the second line of kings, which lasted until the end of the Third Age.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

In 2758, Rohan was invaded by Dunlendings under Wulf, son of Freca, of mixed Dunland and Rohan blood. The King, Helm Hammerhand, took refuge in the Hornburg until aid from Gondor and Dunharrow (a refuge of the Rohirrim) arrived a year later and defeated the invaders.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "https://youtu.be/SLxeNktacYs", "type": "embed"}, {"value": "

It was soon after this that Saruman arrived and took over Isengard, and was welcomed as a strong ally, since it would take Rohan close to 200 years to recover its strength after the invasion.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

In 3014, Saruman began using his influence to weaken the King, Théoden, as part of a campaign to invade or take over the kingdom. In 3019, he launched a great invasion of Rohan, with victory in the two first battles (at the Fords of Isen; Théoden's son, Théodred was killed during these attacks) and defeat at the Battle of the Hornburg, where the Huorns came to the aid of the Rohirrim.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

On the heels of this victory, Théoden rode with an army to Minas Tirith and helped break its siege in the Battle of the Pelennor Fields, where he was slain. Éomer, the nephew of King Théoden, then took up the reign, beginning the third line. Also in this battle, Éowyn, niece of King Théoden and sister of Éomer, slew the Lord of the Nazgûl. Éomer rode with the armies of Gondor to the Black Gate of Mordor and took part in the Battle of the Morannon against the forces of Sauron, who were defeated when the Ruling Ring was destroyed.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

The rule of the Stewards of Gondor was then over. King Éomer and the new king of Gondor, Elessar, renewed their oath of alliance, and reaffirmed Cirion's grant of Calenardhon to the Rohirrim. At this time, Éowyn married Faramir, Prince of Ithilien and Steward of Gondor, thus joining the lines of Gondor and Rohan.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

In the Fourth Age, Rohan remained in peaceful coexistence with the Reunited Kingdom. A Dwarven community developed in the caves of Helm's Deep, which became prosperous from its mining of precious materials.

", "type": "paragraph"}]

[{"value": "

Fangorn (Sindarin: [Fangaorne]; \"Beardtree\") in J.R.R. Tolkien's Legendarium, was a forest located in the fictional world of Middle-earth and was the home of the tree shepherds, the Ents. It was named after the oldest Ent, Treebeard or Treebeard after it. Tolkien did, however, state that there was confusion about the two.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

The Forest of Fangorn provided an important role in The Lord of the Rings novel as did Mirkwood and Lothl\u00f3rien in the Third Age, a time when Sauron challenged Middle-earth to battle and domination. The forest provided the means by where adventure expanded with the breaking up of the Fellowship. Merry Brandybuck and Peregrin Took were the first to discover the Ents were alive but were dwindling in numbers due to the loss of the Entwives. They were lost because of the events of the Last Alliance of Elves and Men. The forest was again severely damaged during the War of the Ring by the forces of Saruman who lived close by in the fortress of Isengard.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"header_text": "Etymology", "size": "h2"}, "type": "header"}, {"value": "

\"Fangorn\" was the original name for the Ent Treebeard, who was the eldest of his species and who looked after vast areas of his home and the surrounding land which was named Fangorn Forest. Additionally, Fangorn translated in the fictional language of Sindarin from \"fanga\" meaning \"beard\" and \"orne\" meaning \"tree\". Sindarin was a language Tolkien created and described the Elves of Middle-Earth to possess; who \"awoke\" the Ents and taught them language. In other parts of Middle-earth Fangorn Forest was called the \"Entwood\" by the Rohirrim.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"attribute_name": "Treebeard", "attribute_group": "", "text": "Some of us are still true Ents, and lively enough in our fashion, but many are growing sleepy, going tree-ish, as you might say. Most of the trees are just trees, of course; but many are half awake. Some are quite wide awake, and a few are, well, ah, well getting Entish. That is going on all the time."}, "type": "blockquote"}, {"value": "

Fangorn Forest apparently had several names as told by Treebeard who referred to the forest by various Quenya names in Lord of the Rings, some of which were Ambar\u00f3na, Tauremornal\u00f3m\u00eb, Tauremorna and Aldal\u00f3m\u00eb. \"Ambar\u00f3na\" means \"uprising, sunrise, orient\" from \"amba\" meaning \"upwards\" and \"r\u00f3na\" meaning \"east\". \"Aldal\u00f3m\u00eb\" means \"tree twilight\" from \"alda\" meaning \"tree\" and \"l\u00f3m\u00eb\" meaning \"dusk, twilight\".[1] \"Tauremorna\" means \"gloomy forest\" from \"taur\" meaning \"forest\" and \"morna\" meaning \"gloomy, somber\".[1] \"Tauremornal\u00f3m\u00eb\" means \"gloomy twilight forest\".

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"header_text": "Geography", "size": "h2"}, "type": "header"}, {"value": "

The Forest of Fangorn was located at the south-eastern end of the Misty Mountains near the Gap of Rohan. The mountains formed the western border of Fangorn. At the end of the mountain range stood the stronghold of Isengard near the southwestern corner of the forest and this was where Saruman lived.[citation needed] To the east and south of Fangorn was the land of Rohan, and Lothl\u00f3rien lay to the north and slightly east. Fangorn Forest stretched for many miles and held many paths.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

Tolkien stated that two significant rivers ran through the forest. To the north the Limlight flowed from the woods and then formed the northern border of Rohan. The river then merged into the larger Anduin. In the south, the Entwash spread deep into the forest arriving from Methedras, a mountainous region located near the Misty Mountains. The river then flowed from Fangorn and was directed through Rohan to the Anduin River. The valley of Derndingle was located to the south-west. There was a path where the Entwash passed into a region called Wellinghall and this was where the Entwash passed the home of Treebeard, the shepherd of the forest.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

Fangorn Forest was said to be humid, and trunks and branches grew thick where very little light penetrated the forest. Similarly, Fangorn was said to be a dangerous and evil place like Mirkwood (where huge spiders roamed the forest and other evil creatures lay), but this was not the case following the events of The Lord of the Rings. The forest was home to many different kinds of trees. Huorns also lived in the forest, similar to Ents but more discreet. Most lived deep in the Forest of Fangorn. The Ents and Huorns drank from the river Entwash, and from it the Ents brewed their legendary drink, the Ent-draughts.

", "type": "paragraph"}]

[{"value": "

The Shire is a region of J. R. R. Tolkien's fictional Middle-earth, described in The Lord of the Rings and other works. The Shire refers to an area settled exclusively by Hobbits and largely removed from the goings-on in the rest of Middle-earth. It is located in the northwest of the continent, in the large region of Eriador and the Kingdom of Arnor. In the languages invented by Tolkien, its name in Westron was S\u00fbza \"Shire\"[1] or S\u00fbzat \"The Shire\",[2] while its name in Sindarin was i Drann.[3]

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"header_text": "Geography", "size": "h2"}, "type": "header"}, {"value": "

According to Tolkien, the Shire measured 40 leagues (193 km, 120 miles[4]) from the Far Downs in the west to the Brandywine Bridge in the east, and 50 leagues (241 km, 150 miles) from the northern moors to the marshes in the south.[5] This is confirmed in an essay by Tolkien on translating The Lord of the Rings,[6] where he describes the Shire as having an area of 18,000 square miles (47,000 km2).[7]

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "https://youtu.be/Ti5OaadrS9I", "type": "embed"}, {"value": "

The original territory of the Shire was bounded on the east by the Baranduin River, on the north by uplands rising to the old centre of Arnor, on the west by the White Downs, and on the south by marshland south of the River Shirebourn. After the original settlement, hobbits also expanded to the east into Buckland between the Baranduin and the Old Forest, and (much later) to the west into the Westmarch between the White Downs and the Tower Hills.[8]

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

The Shire was originally divided into four Farthings. The outlying lands of Buckland and the Westmarch were formally added after the War of the Ring.[5] Within the Farthings there are some smaller unofficial clan homelands: the Tooks nearly all live in or near Tuckborough in Tookland, for instance. A Hobbit surname often indicates where the family came from: Samwise Gamgee's last name derives from Gamwich, where the family originated. Buckland was named for the Oldbucks (later called the Brandybucks).

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

The Shire is described as a small but beautiful, idyllic and fruitful land, beloved by its inhabitants. The Hobbits had an extensive agricultural system in the Shire but were not industrialised. The landscape included small pockets of forest (again similar to the English countryside). Various supplies were produced in the Shire, including cereals, fruit, wood and pipe-weed.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"header_text": "Regions of the Shire", "size": "h2"}, "type": "header"}, {"value": "

The original parts of the Shire were subdivided into four Farthings (\"fourth-ings\" or \"quarterings\").[9] The Three-Farthing Stone marked the tripoint where the borders of the Eastfarthing, Westfarthing and Southfarthing of the Shire came together, by the East Road.[10] (Iceland was traditionally also divided in Farthings, or \"fourth parts\", as the Shire is.) It is claimed that the Three-Farthing Stone was inspired by the Four shire stone.[11]

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": "

Buckland, across the Baranduin River to the east, and the Westmarch, between the Far Downs and the Tower Hills to the west, were not part of the original grant to the hobbits by King Argeleb II of Arthedain. These were formally given to the hobbits as the East and West Marches of the Shire by King Elessar after the War of the Ring, in S.R. 1462 (F.A. 41).[9][12] Buckland had been long settled by then: Gorhendad Oldbuck led hobbits from the East Farthing across the river in T.A. 2340,[12] and Buckland became \"sort of a colony of the Shire\".[13] There is no mention of settlement in the Westmarch until Elessar's gift; Sam Gamgee's daughter Elanor and her husband Fastred later settled there, and Fastred was created Warden of Westmarch.

", "type": "paragraph"}]

[{"value": "

Rivendell is an Elven realm in Middle-earth, a fictional world created by J. R. R. Tolkien. It is an important location in Tolkien's legendarium, and is featured in The Hobbit, The Lord of the Rings, The Silmarillion, and Unfinished Tales. It was established and ruled by Elrond Half-elven in the Second Age of Middle-earth (four or five thousand years before the events of The Lord of the Rings), and was protected by the powers of its lord and his elven ring Vilya.

Elrond lived in Rivendell with his family \u2014 his wife Celebr\u00edan (until she departed for Valinor), their sons Elladan and Elrohir, and their daughter Arwen \u2014 as well as a sizeable number of other Elves, both Noldor and Sindar. In addition to the family of Elrond, notable Elves who lived in Rivendell included Glorfindel, Gildor, and Erestor. In some writings, featured in Unfinished Tales, Galadriel and Celeborn also lived in Rivendell for a time before they became rulers of Lothl\u00f3rien.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"caption": "Gandalf doing awesome things", "image": 26, "style": "half"}, "type": "image"}, {"value": "https://youtu.be/t9L8Er_oqAQ", "type": "embed"}, {"value": {"header_text": "Etymology", "size": "h2"}, "type": "header"}, {"value": {"header_text": "Testing", "size": "h2"}, "type": "header"}, {"value": "

Rivendell\u00a0is a direct translation or\u00a0calque\u00a0into English of the\u00a0Sindarin\u00a0name\u00a0Imladris, both meaning \"deep valley of the cleft\". The name Rivendell is formed by two English elements: \"riven\" (split, cloven) and \"dell\" (valley), making the whole word purport \"deeply cloven valley\". Imladris was also rendered \"Karningul\" in\u00a0Westron, the \"Common Tongue\" of Middle-Earth represented as English in the text of\u00a0The Lord of the Rings.\u00a0It is also referred to as\u00a0The Last Homely House,\u00a0alluding to the elves' old cities, in Beleriand and Aman, and the wilderness (Rhovanion) that lies east of the Misty Mountains.

", "type": "paragraph"}, {"value": {"header_text": "Legacy", "size": "h2"}, "type": "header"}, {"value": {"attribute_name": "Gandalf", "attribute_group": "Fellowship of the Ring", "text": "Evil things do not come into this valley... We are sitting in a fortress. Outside it is getting dark."}, "type": "blockquote"}, {"value": "

In the period of\u00a0counterculture\u00a0in the\u00a0Western World\u00a0of the 1960s and 1970s, a\u00a0commune\u00a0called\u00a0Maos Lyst\u00a0(Mao's Delight) was founded in\u00a0Denmark\u00a0in 1968, its inhabitants replacing their surnames with\u00a0Kl\u00f8vedal, Danish for Rivendell, inspired by Tolkien's Elven outpost.[6]\u00a0Several of them later became well-known cultural personalities in the country.

The Canadian progressive rock band\u00a0Rush\u00a0memorializes Rivendell in the song \"Rivendell\" on their second studio album\u00a0Fly By Night. The song focuses on the tranquillity and seemingly endless time a weary traveller could find there.

The Austrian folk band Rivendell takes the material for their lyrics almost entirely from Tolkien's books.

A Californian manufacturer of bicycles,\u00a0Rivendell Bicycle Works, also uses the name, inspired by the book and a United States backpacking supply company founded in the 1970s called\u00a0Rivendell Mountain Works. They take many of the names of their bicycle models from Tolkien.[7]

", "type": "paragraph"}]
